I am advised that the two principals are Mr Ian Gilbertson and Mr George Gilbertson, who also live in Victoria.

However, the workers employed at the South Grafton Meatworks were employed by two separate companies called R.J. Gilbertson (Qld) Pty Ltd and Giltech Pty Ltd. The directors of these two companies that were employing the workers were Ian and George Gilbertson. So we had a situation where the premises, the infrastructure, the assets of the company, the meatworks themselves, were owned by one company and the workers at the establishment were employed by two separate companies. But both companies, thought seperate legal entities, had the same persons as directors. That is important because of what has recently transpired.

On 7 October 1997 the ANZ bank, which had issued a line of credit, decided that further funding arrangements to the company should cease as it was having difficulty trading and it appointed directors of a chartered accounting firm in Victoria to act as manager-receiver of the company. At that time of appointment, the company owed the workers substantial amounts of money. In the order of $1.8 million was owed in accrued leave entitlements, such as annual leave, sick leave and long service leave. As a result of further events—the employees were terminated—they were also owed around $1.2 million in redundancy and severance pay entitlements.

After the company was put under an administrator, the meat workers union representing the employees cooperated with the administrator to the point where they agreed to reduce their paid working time to two days per week to help the company to continue operating and reduce some of its costs. However, that situation did not lead to any substantial improvement. On 12 December 1997, just two weeks before Christmas, 300 workers were terminated by the Gilbertson company and the meatworks was closed.

At the time the workers were terminated they were not paid any of their entitlements—amounting to $3 million in both accrued leave, severance and redundancy payments. Subsequently, the administrator has paid some 16 per cent of the entitlements to the workers, obviously as a result of assessing the amount owed to the various creditors, including the workers, and making a partial payout. But clearly a substantial amount of money is still owed to the workers. In view of the fact that the company had substantial debts of around $9 million, it is unlikely that the workers will ever be fully paid their lawful entitlements.

I am sure that senators and members of parliament are already aware of the tragic situation that has occurred at Cobar—the amounts involved there are substantially greater—where the Ashanti company just closed the mine and flew the country. This situation at Grafton is another example of employment in the rural sector in this country being affected by company closures and, further, where the workers, who have slaved for many years—in the case of the Grafton meatworks' employees some for over 35 years—are terminated without any of their entitlements being paid out.

There is a range of concerns that I am investigating at the moment with respect to the operations of the Gilbertson company. Requests have been made for the relevant ministers and I understand the Australian Securities Commission to look at the activities of this company over the past few years. I will leave that for another time.

I just want to say to the Gilbertson company directors, Mr Ian and George Gilbertson, who continue to reside in their mansion in Victoria and still have all of their other business interests in their other companies to ensure that they continue to get paid and live as multimillionaires, I am not going to let this one go. I am going to get to the bottom of it. I am going to expose just precisely what has happened and also ensure that the public of Australia know the activities of companies like the Gilbertsons'. When workers are left stranded and when their families are placed in a situation of not only being unemployed but also being unable to get even their lawful entitlements, those companies should not be allowed to go unchallenged. I will pursue that further.

What has happened subsequently? After the meatworks closed and 300 workers just two weeks prior to Christmas were put out on the street, approaches were made to the federal government to give them some assistance, to see if something could be done to have the meatworks reopened because it was one of the major employers in Grafton. I see Senator Boswell is here. He would appreciate the importance of that enterprise in that town.

Approaches were made to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and to Minister Anderson, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. No response. Not interested. Indeed, when the workers' representatives, the union, finally got to meet Minister Anderson it was only by virtue of the good fortune that he happened to be in Grafton and they went along and virtually ensured that he had to talk to them.

I am advised by one of the workers there that, when they were discussing this issue with Mr Anderson, he suggested that maybe one of the problems with the company was that there was too much workers compensation, too much sick leave. What a disgraceful thing to tell workers who have just been sacked without being paid their entitlements—and some of them had worked more than 30 years for that company. What a terrible thing for a minister to suggest.

I want to know why this government has not done a damn thing to help get those meatworks reopened. The Carr government and the local state member, Harry Woods, now the Minister for Regional Development and Rural Affairs in the New South Wales government, have done everything possible to work with the major creditor, the bank, and with potential purchasers to see if these meatworks can be reopened. They have offered concessions in respect to such issues as payroll tax and stamp duty to see if that can be brought about. But the federal government remains absolutely silent. It does not appear to be interested in the issue.

Also, what has the NFF done about this? I have not seen or heard one statement from Mr McGauchie, Mr Hoolihan, Mr Ferguson or any of the other representatives of the NFF about how the government should try to assist employment in rural Australia—not one word. The NFF was quite prepared years ago to put money into supporting a meatworks in the Northern Territory at Mudginberri. Why? Because it was a non-union operation. But where is the NFF now when there is a meatworks in Grafton that needs its support and needs its advocacy? It is silent, but it is not so silent down on the Melbourne waterfront where it is trying to stir up a political dispute simply for its own political and ideological ends.

talk.start.para: —Good work they're doing too.

—According to you they are. But they are doing absolutely nothing for 300 workers and their families in the town of Grafton. You all ought to be ashamed of yourselves. You do not give a damn about these people, but you get out there and talk about how you are going to assist the NFF to take on the wharfies.

speech.para: Why don't you direct your attention to the real issues that are confronting rural Australia? Why don't you do something to support those workers and their families from Cobar? They are Australians, they are workers and they are entitled to some support. But they get nothing from you, nothing from the National Party and nothing from this government. Frankly, I think it is a disgrace.

I have really only just started to draw attention to this issue today. I can assure you that I am going to have plenty more to say and I will continue to expose this government and some of their supporters, such as the Gilbertson family, for the despicable and disgraceful actions that they have taken in regard to decent hardworking employees in rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —Last Sunday I had the pleasure of appearing on the ABC's Speaking out program to discuss an issue which I have had an ongoing interest in—that is, our relationship with our indigenous people. During the program a caller praised the richness of the Aboriginal culture and then went on to denigrate the Australian culture. That comment, unfortunately, epitomises what has gone wrong in the discussion of Aboriginal affairs in this country. The simple fact is that people will naturally identify and feel comfortable within their own cultural parameters.

speech.para: You do not win mainstream support for policies targeting Aboriginal wellbeing by attacking the mainstream Australian culture. It is often said that you do not make yourself taller by trying to cut your opponent off at the knees. In a similar vein, you do not enhance Aboriginal culture by denigrating white culture. A mature approach is to celebrate the richness and diversity of both cultures and also to be even-handed in dealing with those aspects of the cultures which are not uplifting and which are deserving of criticism.

Some spokesmen and commentators appear to labour under a `reverse racism' or `cultural cringe' about white culture. To a certain extent, this has been reflected in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report entitled Bringing them home. Whilst the report has highlighted and reinforced in our national consciousness the shameful way we treated many Aboriginal families, it went overboard to an extent that lost community goodwill, as witnessed by the opinion polls taken at the time.

On 18 June last year, I addressed the Bringing them home report in the adjournment debate, being critical of the arbitrary use of the term `genocide'. The failure to provide balance in the report concerns me. The Australian taxpayer directly funded the inquiry to the tune of $1.5 million—a large sum of money—and the Australian people deserve better.

Since the report was delivered in April 1997, there has been a string of well reasoned critiques of the report which clearly undermine it. I refer to people such as Mr Howson, Dr Partington and Dr Brunton to name a few. In recent times, Sir Ronald Wilson, the former President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, sought to take Dr Brunton to task over his well reasoned critique. In doing so, I believe that Sir Ronald left himself and the whole report exposed by failing to answer the detailed and valid criticisms. For example, on the issue of labelling the well intentioned policies of the time as genocide, Sir Ronald told us, courtesy of the Herald Sun yesterday:
Recommendations were made only where the evidence was overwhelming.

Dispassionate observers would argue that the term `genocide' was inflammatory and unsustainable. It caused damage and was wrong. Nevertheless, Sir Ronald's assurance of `overwhelming evidence' does not ring true when one reads the comments of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner Chris Sidoti in answers to questions I asked on 10 June 1997 about the term `genocide' at a Senate committee hearing.
On page 110 of the Hansard, Mr Sidoti tellingly said:
Perhaps as a last comment I can assure you that there was no single issue in this process that we argued more and longer about ourselves than this issue before we finally came to that conclusion. . .

It is interesting, because that description hardly fits the hyperbole of `overwhelming evidence', especially when it is recalled that one of the commissioners, Mr Mick Dodson, had, prior to the conclusion of the hearing, asserted that assimilation is genocide. A failure then to make the allegation of genocide would have left Mr Dodson with egg all over his face. He would have been left somewhat embarrassed.

Whether this weighed on the commission's corporate mind, I do not know, but there seems little or no other reason for the use of the inflammatory term. Mr Dodson's pre-emptory remarks should have disqualified him from the inquiry. Also, Sir Ronald had a difficult conflict. As a church moderator in the 1960s, he felt he had to apologise for his own role in the removal of children. To quote Sir Ronald:
It is very distressing. I felt I had to apologise even though I had no knowledge of the wrongness of the practice.

I simply ask rhetorically: if, at the time, he did not have any knowledge of the wrongness of the practice, why does he assert that other people engaged in the practice at the time did have that knowledge which he denies for himself.

`Genocide' is a criminal term. Genocide is a crime. How can you commit a crime without having the intention to commit it or the knowledge of what you are doing? This is a very basic legal principle but, when confronted with it himself, Sir Ronald—might I add, quite properly—denies any knowledge of the wrongness of the practice. Might I suggest that the report would have done a lot better if it had given all the other people the benefit of the doubt as well.

In effect, what we had was Mick Dodson drawing conclusions before the inquiry was complete and Sir Ronald inquiring into his own conduct as moderator of a church and then making recommendations. I simply refer to this unfortunate scenario to question the treatment that Justice Callinan has received in recent times in relation to the allegation of apprehended bias. I accept that Justice Callinan could be apprehended as having bias. Indeed, that is why he stood down, but if that is the case and the test, one wonders why Mr Dodson and Sir Ronald, who clearly had actual and glaring bias, were not asked under the same premise to stand down by those who were asking for Justice Callinan to stand down. There has been a strange silence over that undoubted bias.
In the context of this alarmist assertion of genocide—

talk.start.para: —It was genocide.

—it should be recalled that assimilation was a policy strongly supported by international bodies at the time. As Dr Brunton so devastatingly points out, Senator Gibbs, the policy of the ILO—that organisation the Labor Party always bows down to and tugs the old forelock to—in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s was to develop and assimilate indigenous people into modern society. Assimilation was seen as just and desirable.

speech.para: Dr Brunton further quotes a communist trade union official Tom Wright, whose 1939 pamphlet `New Deal for Aborigines' was endorsed by the New South Wales Labour Council and, indeed, the National Missionary Society. The broad spectrum of the community supported this assertion that there was a need to make clear, legislative and administrative distinctions between `full bloods' and `mixed bloods'. Yet the report asserts that mixed race or half-castes, as they were called, were recognised as `children of the group'. I would submit: they clearly were not.

Dr Brunton also cites Marg Harris's revelations made on the Sunday program that her brother, who had a white father, was killed at birth because of his half-caste status. So we are dealing with social views of a time completely different from those which we currently have.

The treatment of Aboriginal families and their children by the removal policy was horrendous. With the benefit of hindsight, we realise that the policy was not beneficial—indeed, it was very negative. But these removal policies were not only limited to our indigenous families. They applied equally and as devastatingly to white children from the poorer sectors of the community and unmarried mothers.

Just last week, I had the honour and privilege of being given an account of a child migrant's turbulent uprooting from the United Kingdom, of being brought to Australia where she was fostered out to what she described as a very loving and caring couple only to be returned to her natural parents in South Africa—where they then were—and where her father sexually abused her. Previously I had been provided with other similar accounts. She came out to Australia in 1954.

The unfortunate fact remains that our concepts of neglect and welfare today are different to those that existed many decades ago. Even on today's standards, Aboriginal children suffer from terribly high rates of neglect and abuse at the hands of their own parents in comparison with the white community. The Central Land Council gave evidence of that to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, on which I serve. There are legion examples of what I would describe as `intellectual laziness' in the report. Some people such as Dr Brunton go even further and describe it as `morally irresponsible'.

Standing back and looking at the debate that has ensued, we have seen the opportunity for the Bringing them home report to provide genuine reflection by Australian society being squandered for advocacy purposes. The opportunity for healing and reconciliation afforded by the inquiry has been prejudiced through intemperate remarks, overstating matters and misrepresenting motives. In doing so, we as a nation can overlook and try to excuse ourselves from focusing on the tragic consequences of the welfare lobby and social engineers interfering in family life.

I am very pleased that the Howard government has not done so, despite what I consider to be the inadequacies of the report. Minister Herron and the Liberal government have come to grips with the real and fundamental issues. That is why, on 17 December last year, a $63 million package of practical assistance was announced that was targeted to provide much needed relief to our Aboriginal brothers and sisters.

In the short time remaining, I will outline some of those benefits: $2 million for Australian Archives to index, copy and preserve thousands of files so that they are more readily accessible; close to $6 million for further development of indigenous family support and parenting programs; $1.6 million to the National Library for an oral history project in recognition of the importance of indigenous people and others telling their stories of family separation; a $9 million boost to culture and language maintenance programs; $11.25 million to establish a national network of family link-up services to assist individuals; $16 million for 50 new counsellors to assist those affected by past policies and for those going through the reunion process; and $17 million to expand the network of regional centres for emotional and social wellbeing and to give counsellors professional support and assistance.

The period of family separations represents a very sad phase in the history of indigenous and non-indigenous relations in this country. It occurred at a time when Australia was developing economically and becoming a force in the region. The general community was prospering, but for many indigenous people it was a time of poverty, helplessness and great personal tragedy. The report Bringing them home has shown us all just how tragic a time it was for many of our indigenous people.

We know that we must never forget the past; that we must learn from the past so that we do not allow such circumstances and policies to happen in our community again. Australia is a decent and harmonious nation with a society which is fundamentally based on fairness, tolerance and mutual respect with an appreciation of racial and cultural diversity. This government is committed to upholding those values. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tasmania's representation as a quality supplier in international markets is well-known. An important step was taken recently to enhance that reputation. In fact, our drive towards quality assurance from paddock to plate has recently taken a major step forward with the establishment of the quality assurance umbrella body for Tasmanian primary industry—the Tasmanian Quality Assurance Incorporated. TQA, as it is known, is a Tasmanian government funded association of industry groups. The need for paddock to plate certification of production standards was identified by Premier Tony Rundle in his direction statement for Tasmania to maximise the state's ability to market high quality produce, both interstate and overseas.

speech.para: Throughout Tasmanian primary industry, various industry groups have been and are involved in implementing their own quality assurance schemes. In a nutshell, these quality assurance schemes are about addressing market requirements and selling more Tasmanian produce now and into the future.

These industry group quality assurance schemes are all different as customer requirements for wool are not the same as those for vegetables. The people involved in implementing quality assurance schemes have found, however, that there are many areas of common interest as most farms run more than one enterprise.

To address these issues, representatives from a number of quality assurance schemes encompassing the meat, wool, apple and vegetable industries, as well as the Egg Marketing Board, have been working together to develop a proposal for an umbrella body. The Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries facilitated the development of a TQA proposal, and the Tasmanian government has provided $300,000 support over a three-year period. The corporate structure of Tasmanian Quality Assurance has been established, a committee of management has been formed, and its first manager has been appointed. The initial committee has been drawn from industry representatives involved in quality assurance, and is headed by Mr Russell Paterson, managing director of Australia's leading speciality cheese manufacturer, Lactos. The committee members have been drawn from a diverse range of primary producers covering the meat, wool, vegetables, egg and fruit industries. A representative from the Department of Primary Industries and Fisheries represents the government's interests.

The TQA committee will prepare a business plan and prioritise issues for implementation. Areas such as auditing, record keeping, trading and promotion are common across many QA schemes. It is considered the aim of TQA that the implementation of quality assurance on farm does not become overly complex or costly. To do so would reduce the interest from the very people the scheme is aiming to assist.

Therefore, the role of TQA will be to ensure that the agreed standards of member schemes can be implemented in a coordinated and cost-effective fashion across Tasmanian primary industry. TQA will provide auditing and other services to member schemes. They will also provide a first stop shop for quality assurance in Tasmanian primary industry. All producers interested in QA will have a single point of contact. Additionally, TQA will investigate the issue of a Tasmanian brand or label for all Tasmanian produce and its quality assurance to agreed minimum standards.

Tasmanian Quality Assurance is supported by the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, and the Australian Quality Council has been consulted. The Tasmanian primary industry group is a growing industry. It is a caring industry and has a very fine future with a need to fulfil customer requirements very firmly set in its sights.

Tasmanian producers are justifiably proud of the excellent reputation of their products on international markets. A visit to Japan to any of their markets will reveal that Tasmania has got its act right and is an acknowledged leader in those markets. That reputation can only be enhanced by initiatives such as Tasmanian Quality Assurance and the paddock-to-plate emphasis promoted and endorsed by the Tasmanian government. I endorse the actions taken and I believe primary industry in our state has a great future.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.55 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the National Assembly of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, led by the Chairman of the National Assembly, His Excellency Mr Nong Duk Manh. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the Chairman to take a place on the floor of the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

para.inline: Mr Nong Duk Manh was thereupon seated accordingly.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade. In view of the admission on page 25 of Mr Fischer's trade statement that the Asian financial crisis will lower profits, reduce domestic spending, adversely affect household incomes, damage business and consumer confidence and cost Australian jobs, will you now tell us why you have not been honest in admitting these facts before? When will these impacts be felt; how deep will they go; how many Australian jobs will be lost; and which industries will be hardest hit?

—I am not sure what Senator Cook is looking to do—one might suggest undermine Australian business and business confidence. Of course there will be some consequences from what is happening in Asia, Senator Cook. What is happening in Asia is quite dramatic. But I can tell you what: the effect upon Australia would be an awful lot worse if we had followed your recipe. If we had continued your policies that gave us $10.3 billion of deficit when we came to government, where would this country be now? If we had not reined in inflation and expenditure, got down interest rates and given Australian business a real opportunity to compete, where would we be now?

answer.para: The cheek of Senator Cook to come in after the record of his government, to which he contributed for some time as trade minister, and seek to give us a lecture! Of course there will be some consequence. We do not know the full details of that consequence. Time will tell. We do not know the full depth of the difficulties in Asia, but we do know that not only have we set the macro-economic parameters so that Australian business has its best opportunity to compete and survive in this very difficult environment but furthermore, as Senator Cook ought to be prepared to acknowledge, we have gone out and supported the IMF arrangements in South Korea, in Indonesia and in Thailand. In other words, we have gone out to support Australian business during this difficult time. All the signs are that we will be able to weather this difficulty in reasonably good shape.

What Senator Cook ought to be doing is giving encouragement and support to Australian business rather than looking for figures in a way to undermine confidence and to in some way then attempt to attribute blame to the Howard government. This contribution does not do you justice or the Labor Party justice, Senator Cook. You ought to lift your eyes a little, lift your horizons, and do something positive for Australian business for a change.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Over the last 12 months the current account deficit has blown out by 23 per cent, foreign debt has hit an all-time high of $222 billion and today the national account figures record lower than expected growth, and all this before the effects of the Asian crisis hit our shores. In view of those damaging statistics, will the government stop hiding the true position from the Australian people and give an unequivocal commitment to promptly put down an honest statement of the impact of Asia on this nation's economic future, including what the revised growth figure is, what the employment impact will be, what will be the impact on the current account deficit and how these changes will affect interest rates? Will you come clean and tell the Australian people what you have been hiding from them up until now? (Time expired)

—As Mr Costello said earlier today, today's national accounts show continuing strong economic growth with the Australian economy growing at 3.6 per cent through the year to the December quarter 1997. Yes, there will be consequences of the difficulties in Asia. The impact of the East Asian financial crisis is showing up through the trade figures, as you say, to some extent, but exports to markets other than Asia remain strong. In the six months to December 1997 compared with the same period in 1996, exports to Japan increased by 18.6 per cent.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. This is not an answer to the question I asked. I asked whether the government will give an unequivocal guarantee to come clean with the Australian people and say what the impacts of the Asian currency crisis are. Madam President, will you ask Senator Hill to answer that question?
—Senator Hill, you should apply yourself to the question as asked and answer it.

—Obviously the government has been giving a full and accurate account. What I am saying to Senator Cook is that, in his efforts to undermine the Australian economy, he ought to take into account that, although exports to Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia have fallen slightly, exports to Japan have gone up by 18.6 per cent in the quarter I mentioned, to China by 22 per cent, to Singapore by 31 per cent, to Taiwan by 26 per cent and to Hong Kong by 45 per cent. That is actually good news, Senator Cook. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Minister, you would be aware that for 13 years the Labor Party turned a blind eye to the rorts on the waterfront. What is the government doing to improve the competitiveness and the productivity of the waterfront and are there any threats to these vital reforms?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We are doing quite a lot. Thanks to the invaluable assistance of the shadow minister for the selfish `me generation' yuppies, who was instrumental in ensuring that we got industrial relations reforms through this parliament, we now have in place a regime that does offer opportunities to employers to deliver real productivity gains. Quite clearly, freedom of association arrangements, ending monopoly rorts on the waterfront and, of course, making sure that secondary boycotts are not able to used to stymie reforms, are critically important as well.

answer.para: But the real problem, Madam President, is not our support. We are there in spades when it counts. The real problem is the Labor Party because the Labor Party, as Senator Boswell rightly said, for the last 13 years has been burying its head in the sand. It is pretty obvious why. Because the Labor Party is a wholly owned subsidiary of the trade union movement. You know who happens to be in the parliament this very day? A delegation from the MUA central New South Wales branch. I suppose they have seen you, Senator Faulkner, have they? They have been working their way through the list. They are wanting assurances that you will maintain cabotage. They are wanting to be assured that a strong and well-organised Australian shipping industry is vital to the economy, the community and the environment. In other words, they want to keep on with the great racket—the greatest scandal in Australian political history and one that you have condoned repeatedly.

The Labor Party has said nothing on this issue. We stand fairly and squarely behind the need for dramatic improvements on the waterfront. What has this mob done about crane rates of 18 per hour compared with those of our competitors of 25 to 30 per hour? Absolutely nothing. I hesitate to call Mr Beazley gutless, but the fact is that he has said virtually nothing on this issue. But when he did say something recently about this, he simply took the opportunity to bag the Howard government. What he said was: the people who work on the waterfront are prepared to sit down and talk these issues through. We know they are prepared to sit down and talk; we want to know when they will stand up and work!

The fact is that you are not interested in reforms, yet you had the breathtaking gall and hypocrisy to pass a motion at the national conference in January that Labor will work constructively with waterfront users by encouraging greater competition through new stevedoring operations. It is breathtaking, Madam President. What have you done to demonstrate any commitment at all to that? Simply mealy mouthed words which you hope will get you through.

The fact is, of course, they are terribly embarrassed. They know full well that this mob have rorted the system for years. They dudded you every time you tried to engage in reforms. When Mr McMullan was recently asked whether the MUA had his unequivocal support, he simply said, `It is not a matter of unequivocal support.' The fact is, as Graham Richardson said recently, you cannot expect the ALP to do anything else because they are simply beholden to the trade union movement. He is absolutely right, and that is what is going to continue to happen in this vital area.

I ask the Labor Party and Labor senators in this place to get up and say whether they support the rorts that are going on, these $110,000 a year silvertails getting money for about 30 hours a week. Do you support that? Do you support what is going on at the moment? Are you really in favour of competition? Of course you are not because you are not allowed to be. You have been given your riding orders. You have been told at the very least to say nothing; to sit on the sidelines. You are not even game to get out there and criticise the MUA, even though you know 60 per cent of Australians think it is an absolute racket that has been going on for far too long. This is a critical issue, one that will be vital in the electorate, and you have already been found wanting. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, isn't it true that Mr Campbell of your department has confirmed that Mr Cosier, a member of your personal staff, instructed the department to review rejected or ineligible NHT funding applications from Victoria? Why won't you tell us when your office issued that direction, and what representations were made to you and your office, and by whom, prior to the direction being issued?

—Madam President, we are back to it again: the slanders and slurs of yesterday. Do you remember Senator Faulkner yesterday including Maurice Howard Lawrence Baillieu within his slander? Do you remember that? Madam President, he died in 1961. Thirty-seven years ago he died. What about the slander yesterday of Richard Percy Clive Baillieu? He died 57 years ago, in 1941. What about John Madden Baillieu? He got a serve yesterday. We were told that he was chairman of EL&C Baillieu. He is an old man of over 80 who retired from that job nearly three years ago.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It shows what a grubby exercise you are up to here. He died three years ago, Madam President. He died when the Labor Party was in office, as a matter of interest.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You might think this is funny, Senator Cook. Yesterday you were slandering the living—but apparently also the dead. The mathematics of the donation, Senator Ray, are very interesting. Our research to date does not add up to the figure that you set out here—the coincidental figure that served your purposes out of this place and got a story for you. Our figures do not add up to that. It is interesting, so you might disclose it.

answer.para: It seems, Madam President, that for at least a substantial part of the donations, they were made when Labor was in office as well. What is this all about? Why have you dragged the Baillieu family out like this? Why don't you go outside and slander the Baillieus in the same way, rather than using this coward's castle?

This is what this question is all about. You said that in some way we improperly gave the Baillieus a benefit, that they were part of some conspiracy to get a benefit. And you went further and implied that they gave it back to the Liberal Party. These facts do not substantiate what you said. You did not do your homework. You slandered this family, and you behaved disgracefully.
What did Mr Antony Baillieu say in this morning's paper? He said:
It's very disappointing. The politicians, the slanderous statements they make about people,—
that is you, Senator Faulkner—
. . . the slanderous statements they make about people, they're too busy talking, if they've gave it a little bit more thought, and thought half the time they bloody well spoke—
that is you, Senator Faulkner—
they'd come out with considerably more useful stuff, instead of pursuing rubbish like this. It's rubbish, total rubbish . . . I can tell you now, there is absolutely no snout in the trough.
Do you still say the Baillieus have their snout in the trough? You go outside—

talk.start.para: —Yes. I say you go outside—

—Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber and shouting at each other across the chamber. I can scarcely hear what is being said; I doubt that anyone else can either. Senator Hill, address your remarks through the chair.
—We will see if Senator Faulkner goes outside and slanders this family again today. That will be a test of how big a man he is.

answer.para: But the point is, Madam President: I have said that I take responsibility for the fact that my department reviewed projects that were unsuccessful at the RAP and SAP level in Victoria. I have explained why they did it. Do you want me to go through it all again? Do you want me to tell you the deficiencies in the RAP process. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Hill can shiver and shake and shout all he likes at the microphone, but what I want to know is this: I want to know, Senator Hill, when your office issued the direction to your department to review the rejected or ineligible Natural Heritage Trust applications; I want to know what representations were made to you and your office, and I want to know who they were made by prior to that direction being issued? So I ask you, Minister, to answer the question directed to you.

—Madam President, I do not know what he is on about. What I have said is that I take full responsibility for my department reviewing the unsuccessful projects in Victoria. I have said, because of the deficiencies in the RAP in relation to this Eynesbury project—that you like to call the Baillieu project so that you can attack the Baillieu family—that apparently the federal representative was not even on that particular RAP.

answer.para: I explained the SAP deficiencies in this place as well—the fact that the SAP in Vic toria was divided into another sub-component did not give a total consideration of the matter. So why shouldn't we reassess the projects to see if there were any mistakes?

They looked at 199, from memory, Madam President, and found three that they recommended I should fund. I did that. This one had been disallowed by mistake—error—at the RAP level. Why should this excellent project suffer simply because the RAP made an error? You ought to be coming in here and applauding what was done, which is designed to achieve a better environmental outcome. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a question for the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Labor recently dumped its ridiculous three mines policy on uranium mining and replaced it with what it calls a `no new mines policy', although apparently those sitting opposite have not yet decided what constitutes a new mine. My question is: how does this new policy, as claimed by Labor, produce certainty for this industry when the ALP leader in the Northern Territory describes it as `offensive' and `nonsense'? Will the minister inform the Senate what impact, if any, this new policy will have on the industry?
—The minister's answer should be confined more to his area of responsibility and less to Labor Party policy.

—Thank you, Madam President. I think it is interesting to look at the history of uranium mining in Australia, and particularly at the erratic and illogical history of the Labor Party going back to the 1970s. In the 1970s we had the Labor Party not only wanting uranium mining but also uranium enrichment.

—Could I take a point of order, Madam President? It took Senator Parer only 10 seconds to be in breach of your ruling, which drew his attention to what he can answer—that is, the last part of Senator Eggleston's question, which was not on opposition policy; most of the question was directed to opposition policy. I would have thought, implied in your ruling, that you ruled that out. But Senator Parer is immediately into it with a prepared answer.

—On the point of order, Madam President: I think I am describing the history of uranium mining in Australia going back to the 1970s as a lead-up to the answer to the question asked by Senator Eggleston.
—A history may be relevant, but it should be kept as a history rather than Labor Party policy.

—It is a history. Madam President, back in the 1980s, the government of the day adopted what they called a three mines policy. But do you know what it was, Madam President? It was a two mines policy. They could not even count. So what that meant, Madam President, was that we had good uranium from two mines—the Ranger and Olympic Dam mines—but the uranium from other mines was bad uranium.

answer.para: Since the last election there have been some sensible proposals, particularly by people like Senator Quirke, who referred to nuclear energy reducing CO2 emissions. It might be interesting for the Senate to recognise that one of the Japanese responses to greenhouse in Kyoto was that they were going to build more nuclear power stations. Guess where they would like to get the uranium? They would like to get most of it from Australia, as they do right now. But, as Senator Eggleston has pointed out, the current opposition position on this is at odds with the government position. Our position is to say, `Let's have uranium mining, but let's do it in a way that is environmentally effective and where uranium is used only for peaceful purposes in power stations.'

What has this irrelevant group come up with now? It is very important, because the uranium industry is a growth industry in Australia, and some 19 per cent of electricity throughout the world is generated from uranium. Our major markets are Japan, Korea, the European Union and the United States. What the new policy means is that they have gone the full circle. They are now saying that mines developed under the coalition will be bad uranium and other uranium will be good uranium. This is really sensible stuff isn't it?
The shadow minister, poor Stephen Smith, attempted to describe this at a conference in Adelaide and, to his credit, tried to defend the indefensible. Let me tell you exactly what he said:
In short it is a new political lexicon:—
that is nice, isn't it; that went over well with them—
Three mines becomes `no new mines'. Upon return to office a Labor Government will allow export of uranium only from those mines in existence on our return.
At Conference, and subsequently I have been asked to define or delineate what is a new mine and what is an existing mine—
you have to listen to this; I ask all senators: what is a new mine and what is an existing mine?—
Firstly this is not something in respect of which you can make a judgement about in the abstract—
certainty—
It is not something you can make a judgement about now. You can only do that in the concrete. In other words, you can only do that on day one of a Beazley Labor Government.
Clear as mud. What did he say on ABC radio on 27 January? With regard to defining a mine, he said:
As I said to the conference, that's not a judgment you can make in the abstract. At the moment you can say with absolute certainty, I think, that there are only two existing uranium mines . . .

There are a lot of quotes from people on the other side, apart from those of Senator Quirke and Senator Collins, but the one that most sticks in my mind is a beauty. It is the one of then Senator Gareth Evans.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you be specific about the impact of the development of further uranium mines on the Australian economy?

—The effect will be that we will create investments, exports and jobs. I could not help but notice that Senator Cook comes in here with the gall to talk about the current account deficit when the whole range of their policy is to attack it by not allowing mines. But the best quote, as I said, was one by former Senator Evans on nuclear safeguards. On 18 September 1995, he said in response to Senator Kernot:

answer.para: If you do not understand that, you do not understand the way in which the safeguard system operates. If you do not understand that, you do not understand what has kept the world relatively free of nuclear weapons proliferation for the last generation. If you do not understand the dimensions of this subject, you should not be opening your mouth Senator Kernot, in public because every time you do you make an idiot of yourself.
That was just under three years ago. Senator Evans went on to say:

We are actively encouraging not only the existing uranium producers but also the Roxby Downs joint venturers to seek to get into those markets and engage in continuing discussions with them about ways in which that might be assisted.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Can you explain why the Crane project, the Yallobup Creek Catchment Group, does not appear in either the FOI list of projects in WA provided to the Australian newspaper, or in the consolidated list of projects disaggregated by state which your Department provided to the shadow minister? The documents you tabled show the Crane family and other members of the landcare group sought over $300,000 in NHT funds over four years. How much funding did you approve; when did you approve it; and what is the reason these details were not published?

—The honourable senator goes very close to misleading in that question but not quite as close as Mr Kerr yesterday. Honourable senators will remember that in this place I said that Senator Crane gained no benefit from this application at all. In the other place, what did Mr Kerr, the shadow spokesman, then ask the Prime Minister? I quote:

answer.para: Is the Prime Minister aware that the Minister for the Environment has acknowledged in the Senate that a NHT grant benefited Senator Crane?

And you did pretty much the same thing in that question then. What I said yesterday was confirmed by Senator Crane in his personal explanation, which you may not have read. I hope that you did not, because that might explain your question. Yesterday he said that he had made no application, he is to get no benefit from it, and that has been confirmed by those who are running the project. I would have thought that was clear. So why don't you put that to one side instead of trying to slur yet another person unfairly?

The other part of the question was why it was not referenced to this project in response to an FOI. I have no idea, Senator. I had no idea that it was not included, but now that you have brought it to my attention I will follow it up and get you an answer.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, my question is directed to you. Last year a group called Defenders of Native Title organised a human ring around Parliament House which involved over 1,000 people linking hands. Were you satisfied that the demonstration was conducted in a disciplined, peaceful and courteous manner? If you were, why did you and the Speaker of the House refuse permission for an identical procedure today? Why do the Presiding Officers consider the peaceful holding of hands and the display of political messages from the same group and in the same way as a subversive threat to security?

—I know of no suggestion that anything of that kind was said. The words `a subversive threat to security' are words of yours and of no-one else that I know of, Senator. Six months or so ago, a request was granted for this purpose. It was understood at that time to be a one-off situation. It was requested again this week and we indicated that the appropriate place for demonstrations was at the front of the building. It was also indicated that if people walked around the building that would not be out of order and, if it was peaceful, no notice would be taken of it, but that no placards should be taken. I saw people walking around in this area with placards, contrary to what I understood had been agreed would take place.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that today's walking demonstration was again entirely peaceful, courteous and disciplined, would you consider a more positive response if another request of the same kind were made by this group?

—It is a hypothetical question. Any requests for the use of this building for demonstrations are looked at at the time and considered in the light of what has occurred previously and what we believe is in the best interests of people who wish to demonstrate. It is not possible to have demonstrations all around the building at the whim of those who wish to do so. There is a place at the front of the building where orderly demonstrations do take place and which are properly organised between those who wish to demonstrate and the security officers of this building. I believe the system works very well—most people cooperate.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, given that you have denied that the member for Leichhardt, Mr Warren Entsch, was present when you took decisions on the Queensland applications for Natural Heritage Trust funding, will you now confirm that you had extended discussions with Mr Entsch in relation to those applications? Following any discussions, were any revisions made to the recommendations of the Queensland state assessment panel—any changes to the rankings of applications, any late applications assessed or accepted—and, if so, what were the reasons for the changes?

—If I understand it properly, what we are being condemned for is attempting to do the job thoroughly. In other words, what we are being condemned for is treating each application seriously and, as much as possible, assessing it at the Commonwealth level. That is what we are being condemned for here. It is interesting. What is the case? The case is that, as a result of doing the job properly, we exercised some improper decision that led to advantage to the coalition.

answer.para: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, you did. That is what you said when this started. You started con demning the process because the majority of funds went to what you said were coalition seats. Then, when it was pointed out that we held 40 rural seats and you held three, that sounded rather hollow, so then you turned it around and you started attacking the proponents and you attacked the Baillieus. Of course, you got it wrong again because the Baillieus also happened to be in a Labor seat. So be it. You did not happen to mention that, because that did not suit your argument.

answer.para: We have sought to do this job properly and we have sought to assess all the applications. We did not get to assess them all—we have not even been able to get them all from the states—but we sought to assess all the applications as far as we were able.

Before I get to that, let us see what the judgment is of the unbiased observers of this process as to whether it is politically biased. Interestingly, today conservation councils around Australia released a letter—the greens organisations, I might say. They are not generally seen to favour us. What do they say? They said:
However, we have seen no evidence that projects were approved according to political advantage in Coalition held electorates.
They saw no evidence at all. You are determined to find it, but the conservation groups, which are much closer to the ground—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. You might recall that I asked Senator Hill a question in relation to the involvement or the possible involvement of Mr Entsch in this process. I asked him if he could confirm the extent of discussions. I also asked him whether revisions were made to recommendations of the Queensland panel—any changes to rankings of applications—and whether any late applications were assessed or accepted. I ask you, Madam President, now that we have had another two-minute effort to duck this question—just like the other questions that have been asked of him have been ducked in question time—to direct the minister to answer the question.
—I do draw the minister's attention to the question.

—Certainly. Thank you, Madam President. I am just going to the motive of the question before answering the substance. I will put it in another way. I will give you the final sentence of the conservation councils' letter. They said:

answer.para: The Natural Heritage Trust is designed to facilitate action from the ground-up, but with the coordination, leadership and oversight of the Commonwealth. This is the role of any federal government. This is why Ministers Anderson and Hill have scrutinised all projects—so that the outcomes promised, are delivered. We should expect nothing less.

So the greens organisations around Australia are saying that they would expect nothing less than the level of scrutiny that we have given applications for this project. We wanted to give it that scrutiny because we are committed to the Natural Heritage Trust. We are not wanting to wreck it like the Labor Party. We see that it can bring enormous advantage to Australia. It is addressing the neglect of the previous government in relation to natural resource management issues.

The department, when it was reassessing unsuccessful SAP grants in Queensland, provided a brief to me on eight projects. It recommended that four of those projects be approved and I accepted their recommendation.

talk.start.para: —The question was about Mr Entsch.

—Mr Entsch, like many politicians—including your leader, Mr Beazley, and your spokesman—has lobbied me in relation to particular projects. There is no secret about that. Your environment spokesman last wrote to me last week asking that a project be looked at. There is no secret about that. Apparently, according to my department, when the Cairns council project was—(Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, why won't you answer direct questions about extended discussions you had with Mr Entsch in relation to these applications? Why won't you tell us whether there are any revisions from the SAP recommendations, any late applications assessed or accepted? Why won't you tell us when Mr Cosier in your office directed Victoria to reassess? Why won't you tell us about the representations that you received at that time? Why won't you tell us about how much funding you approved for the Crane project? Why won't you tell us when you did approve it? Why won't you tell us what the reasons for that were? Why won't you answer the questions properly directed to you in question time by opposition senators? Perhaps it is because this is a massive rort.

—`This is a massive slander' would have been a better thing to add to the question, Senator. You will drag anyone down in an attempt to serve your short-term political interests. It does not matter who it is. But I bet you have not got the guts out there to have another go at the Baillieus. I do not think you listened to the answer. I said that the department gave me further advice on eight projects. It recommended the funding of four of them. I accepted the recommendation. The Cairns City Council one, which was an excellent project—

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Will you give me the chance to give some details of that? The Cairns City Council one, an excellent project, was among them, and the department advisers, when they gave their objective advice to me, knew of no representation from Mr Entsch.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. I ask the minister, as Australia's premier environmental officer, will you join those conservationists who are trying to protect the Mother Cummings Peak forest and the Great Western Tiers against the destruction which is occurring there today in national estate value forests? Secondly, I ask, in light of Senator Parer's information to a Senate committee last year that, following the regional forest agreement, Commonwealth action on forests in East Gippsland transferred to the Prime Minister's department, was it you or the Prime Minister who gave the go-ahead for the illegal logging in the Goolengook River heritage zone in Victoria last year and this year? What action are you taking, in response to the court's finding in East Gippsland last week that that logging has no legal basis, to see that logging halts not only in Goolengook but in East Gippsland until the mess you created is sorted out and until a lawful basis is found for continued logging?

—We are pleased with the progress we have made in relation to regional forest agreements. After the mess that we inherited as well from Senator Faulkner, I might say, I am pleased that we were able to achieve a regional forest agreement in East Gippsland. I am pleased that we are close to achieving one in the central highlands in Victoria. I am pleased that we have been able to achieve one in Tasmania. I am pleased with the progress we are making towards achieving one in Western Australia, which I expect to be complete within the next few months. If we had got a bit more cooperation from the New South Wales state government we would be closer to achieving one in Eden as well so, if you have any influence, Senator, you might pass that on to your mates back in Sydney.

answer.para: Why am I pleased? I am pleased because it gives the opportunity for this country, in an unprecedented way, to preserve the best of conservation values in those forests, while at the same time allowing industry to grow and to employ with certainty through sustainable forestry practices—ecologically sustainable practices and economically sustainable practices. That was the purpose of the program we have set in place.

I have to say that I thought the outcome in Tasmania with respect to what the honourable senator seems to be referring to today was an excellent one. It cost the Commonwealth quite a bit of money, but we were prepared to put that into providing long-term sustainable jobs within the industry.

talk.start.para: —How many jobs? Zip!
—Are you criticising that?

—Madam President, on a point of order: it is halfway through the answering time for this question and the minister has not addressed the specific questions which I put to him, including the ques tion as to whether he or the Prime Minister authorised the illegal logging in Goolengook.
—A number of questions were posed initially, and I believe that Senator Hill has been addressing them. There are others still unanswered.

—Madam President, I thought the first question was about the Great Western Tiers. I was saying that I believe that the outcome in Tasmania was an excellent outcome, but there are always some who are not prepared to accept a fair outcome; particularly a fair outcome in relation to jobs. This government is committed to good environmental outcomes, but it is also committed to providing Australian jobs and, in this instance, Tasmanian jobs.
—Tell us how many jobs in Tasmania. Tell us? How many? Zip!

—In Tasmania we can, pursuant to that agreement, now have an excellent conservation regime, but at the same time give the industry greater hope than it has ever had before, Senator. As a coalition member, I am proud of that.

answer.para: In relation to the recent litigation in Victoria, I am advised that this matter relates to a point of law concerning the Victorian Heritage Rivers Act 1992. I am not aware of any implications of the decision for the regional forest agreement that this government signed last year. The Victorian government, I am told, is currently seeking legal advice on the matter, but I understand that it is likely that the Victorian government will appeal the decision. It would, therefore, be inappropriate for me to comment further at this stage.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in the meantime, on the basis of legal advice which I have furnished to your office, is it not true that there is a prima facie case that continued logging in East Gippsland is illegal? Are you going to act on that, as the primary environmental officer in this country, or is your inactivity going to stand as testimony to the continuing fact that instead you are Australia's premier bio-stitute?

—I think that is supposed to be amusing, Madam President. The point is that we believe we have a good outcome for the environment and a good outcome for jobs in East Gippsland as well as in Tasmania. A point of law has now arisen under the Victorian legislation. That point of law will ultimately be determined in higher courts. I have said, Senator, it would be inappropriate for me to delve further into that matter at this time.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, can you explain how, according to documentation provided to the shadow Minister for the Environment, a project entitled `Managing Tilapia to minimise spread in the Barron' received $19,200 under bushcare as project No. 972008 and a further $19,200 under the fisheries action program as project No. 972116? Why did you decide to fund this project in this way? Did the federal member for Leichhardt, Mr Entsch, discuss this project with you?

—This was one of those projects that I referred to earlier that the department advised me I should approve, which advice I accepted. I am told that following approval of the project, the department discovered that the Barron River project had been funded by DPIE through the fisheries action program. Funding through bushcare was, therefore, not pursued.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you explain why these two projects and another bushcare project in Cairns for $31,000 entitled `Incentives and recognition for the protection of freehold land for conservation values' were not listed in the material FOI-ed by the Australian ?
—No, Madam President, but what I can tell you, now that I have been given the chance, is of the importance of the Cairns project. This project was proposed by the Cairns City Council.
—Answer the question.

—You might not be interested, but it is vitally important because it leads to better environmental outcomes in this country. It is an innovative and very worthwhile project because it was the Cairns City Council, looking for ways to provide incentives, that will lead to—
—A life member of the Labor Party.

—If the Labor Party pushed the project, I congratulate the Labor Party. Perhaps they ought to have a talk to some of their Labor senators down in this place because it was showing leadership. We are looking for ways for local government to provide incentives that will, in turn, provide people with better environmental practices. This was a project whereby the Cairns City Council was exploring a range of incentives. It was innovating a leadership program and, according to my department, well worth supporting. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Minister, previously you have confirmed that the coalition government is supporting Mr Skase's bankruptcy trustee's actions to recover assets by way of legal action. Senator Bolkus, the exposed leaker of Federal Court documents, has claimed, I would submit falsely, that the government delayed legal action against Mr Skase. Minister, did you delay signing any documents?

—I thank Senator Abetz for his continued interest in the Skase matter and in Senator Bolkus's incompetence. Senator Bolkus has alleged that there was a delay on numerous occasions on my part in signing certain documents. He says I have held up service of injunctions. He made the allegation at the same press conference he leaked the confidential Federal Court documents at. Senator Bolkus has made these allegations with no evidence whatsoever. That never inhibits Senator Bolkus saying something. Nonetheless, he has gone ahead because he will say or do anything to get publicity for himself and he could see the Skase matter as an easy way to get himself a run in the media.

answer.para: There was no delay in signing any documents in my office. Do you know why there was no delay in signing any documents? Because there were not any documents. Mr Donnelly does not need to come and say to the Minister for Justice, `Can I serve these documents today?' You kid yourself if you think you have that right. You have it wrong again, Senator Bolkus. You have been making misleading and deceptive statements with a reckless disregard for the truth.

Hearing those allegations, I thought I had better check with Mr Donnelly, Mr Skase's trustee, for his advice on these matters and he replied. He said he was aware of the various allegations of delay that had been published in the media recently.

talk.start.para: —It is taking you two months to serve it—60 days.
—Senator Bolkus, you can pursue this matter at the appropriate time, which is not now.
—He wanted to assure me that both he and his lawyers, that is both he and Allens—
—She continues to lie.
—`She continues to lie', is that what you said, Senator Bolkus?
—I ask you to withdraw, Senator Bolkus.
—I withdraw.
—You should stand up when you are requested to address the Chamber.
—I withdraw, Madam President.

—You see, you keep getting it wrong. What Mr Donnelly said is, `I and my lawyers have been most satisfied with the prompt assistance given by you and officers of Attorney-General's Department which have enabled us'—

answer.para: he goes on to make it perfectly clear—`which have enabled us to maintain our planned timetable.' He goes on to point out that his funding has been sufficient as well. Why would Mr Donnelly give me such a letter if he believed what Senator Bolkus was saying was true? I will table the letter.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus, you are persistently interjecting.

—Senator Bolkus has no credibility whatsoever in the Skase matter. He has leaked Federal Court documents; we have caught him doing that. He alleges the government can reopen the Skase extradition; we have shown that that is not possible and we have shown that he knew it was not possible. He alleges delay of service of documents as a consequence of some failure in my office and we have shown that that is not correct either. Either he has a reckless disregard for the truth or he has been sucked in by someone. In any event, he is either reckless or stupid and should not have his job.

answer.para: Court orders were obtained on 1 December in Australia, on 5 December in the United Kingdom and on 8 December in the Cayman Islands, all of which was well known to a small number of people in the government. Why weren't those documents served? The reason the documents were not served at the time is that we thought it might tip everybody else off, so we would wait. Then, when the Federal Court affidavit was released, we had to serve, but Skase already had notice. That is why you see the unedifying picture of people throwing a summons over a fence—because you tipped them off.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. The answer is totally irrelevant to the question because—
—Senator Bolkus, what is the point of order?

—Madam President, the answer is totally irrelevant to the question because the minister knows full well that it is her office that has been investigated for the initial leak to David Luff from the Australian . Government sources were revealed in that article and you should address the fact that you are being investigated yourself.
—There is no point of order.
—Senator Bolkus has also made some allegations that some 50—

answer.para: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus, I have already indicated that I regard you as interjecting persistently. I am considering whether it is wilful.

—They are the facts of the matter. A sensible decision was made by Mr Donnelly in consultation with the Insolvency Trustee Service of which I was advised and asked my opinion as to whether it was best to hold off service until the rest of the proceedings had been carried forward, until another opinion had been gained in Spain. My advice on that matter was that, yes, I did agree with that. But once Senator Bolkus went out and said—(Time expired)

—Madam President, because of Senator Bolkus's continual interruptions I did not quite hear all of the minister's answer. I was wondering whether the minister could confirm for me and the Senate that there were no documents to be signed by you and, as a result, the allegations made by Senator Bolkus are completely without foundation.

—I can confirm that there were no documents in relation to service of any proceedings that were required to be signed by me. I can also indicate this: Senator Bolkus said that $50 million in assets had been pinpointed. This, of course, gets the ear of the media. Well, Senator Bolkus, I challenge you today to go to Mr Donnelly and tell him where the assets are. You tell him about the company structures that you know about. You tell him about the trusts, the holdings and who has got all this money, because nothing like $50 million has been pinpointed. You were just raving on to get yourself a story. Now you can put up or shut up. Admit to the media that you have lied to them, that you have made up a story; that no such pinpointing of $50 million has been made. In your dreams, you pick a figure out of the air to get yourself some publicity and you should be sacked. If your leader was not so weak, you would have been sacked in January. But he should sack you now.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Is the minister aware that the Australian Electoral Commission uses a category of electorate called provincial seats, and that the ALP holds eight such seats to the coalition's 10? Can he explain how it is that the eight ALP provincial seats received an average of $50,650 from the Natural Heritage Trust while the 10 coalition seats received an average of $243,680? How could his objective, transparent assessment and selection process have possibly produced such a skewed result?

—Apart from the slur at the end, it is actually an interesting question and is worth exploring. It is not easy to explore because there were over 6,000 applications. Nevertheless, the Labor Party has requested of us—which we said that we will seek to meet—copies of at least an abbreviation of all 6,000 applications. Just a little job, just a little diversion for the Public Service, just another big expenditure; but we will do it. When we have done it, you and we will be able to make a better comparison and see what the explanation was. I suspect that part of the explanation might be that Labor seats did not put in the same number of applications. One of the reasons for that—
—They knew it was fixed—that's why.

—Is that why? One of the reasons for that is that Labor has no interest in the bush. It is no coincidence that Labor holds three rural seats and the coalition holds 40. They rejected Labor because Labor has no interest in the bush. You are insensitive to the needs in the bush. You do not understand the environmental damage that has been done in the bush. You were never prepared in government to address the issues. You are angry because the coalition has picked up the ball, set in place the Natural Heritage Trust, got it funded, despite your objection, and is now putting unprecedented money onto the ground to make good this environmental damage.

answer.para: You are also angry that it is being done less through state agencies and more through community groups. The Labor Party does not like anything about this trust. The trust supports individuals and community groups to resolve their own problems. It targets the areas of greatest need. It requires efforts to ensure full value for each dollar. It requires a catalytic effect so that you can build upon it to give a better total outcome.

Senator, you ought to take some notice of what the conservation groups are saying. They are not our friends but they do recognise that we have made a fair attempt at the start of this massive project to address the major land and water degradation problems facing Australia, which is more than your people ever did.

Eventually, when we have all this information to hand, we can trawl through it again, as you have already started to try to do with the information you have—you have actually been provided with more information than I have—and we will get a better picture. I hope the answer is not that Labor seats did not bother to apply for funding, but we will see in due course.
Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talk.start.para: —In question time yesterday, Senator Lees asked me about an alleged conflict of interest under standing order 27(5) on the part of Senator Crane in relation to the Natural Heritage Trust fund and inquiries undertaken by the Rural and Regional Affairs Legislation and References Committees, of which Senator Crane is a member. Senator Crane's personal explanation later in the day indicates that he is not an applicant for a grant from the Natural Heritage Trust fund and will not receive any grant from that fund. There is therefore no question of a conflict of interest.

speech.para: Senator Lees also asked what course of action would be taken if a conflict of interest existed contrary to standing order 27(5). It is for senators in the first instance to ensure that a conflict of interest does not arise contrary to the standing order. If the Senate became aware of such a conflict of interest, it would be for the Senate to rectify it by changing the membership of a committee if necessary. There is no precedent of the Senate taking such action.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) to questions without notice asked today, relating to the allocation of grants from the Natural Heritage Trust.

Today, again, we have seen the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) either unwilling or unable to answer a series of important questions that have been directed to him. After three days of solid questioning, we still have the Minister for the Environment unable to answer when a direction was issued from his office to the Department of the Environment to reassess unsuccessful applications in Victoria. We want to know who made representations to Senator Hill; he has not answered that either. They are important questions because three projects were approved as a result of that direction, one of which was a grant to the Baillieu family in Victoria, and we all know about that.

Senator Hill is not willing or able to explain the fact that Senator Crane's project—the Yallobup Creek Catchment Group project—does not appear on the FOI list of projects in Western Australia that was provided to the Australian newspaper; nor does it appear in the disaggregated material that has been made public to date. The opposition asked Senator Hill questions in relation to a grant that has got a lot of focus in both the parliamentary chamber and the public arena. We wanted to know how much funding he approved. He could not or would not answer it. We wanted to know when he approved it. He could not or would not answer it. We wanted to know why those details were not published. He could not or would not answer it.

When it came to the issue of Mr Entsch, we have had no information about the extent of Senator Hill's discussions with Mr Entsch. What we have heard is that Senator Hill had up to 15 hours of discussions with Mr Entsch about grants in Queensland and we wanted to know whether, following those discussions, revisions were made to recommendations of the Queensland state assessment panel, whether the rankings of applications were changed and whether there were any late applications assessed or accepted. What was the reason for the changes if they came about as a result of that process? They are reasonable questions and a competent and responsible minister should be able to answer them.

What we heard from Senator Hill in answer to a question from Senator West was this. He said, `You've been provided with more information than I have.' Senator Hill is the minister who took responsibility for approving all these grants. He is the minister who rolled over the regional assessment panel recommendations, who changed the state assessment panel recommendations, who ignored his own department's recommendations. This is the minister who took responsibility himself for making these decisions, and he has got the hide to come in here and say that we had been provided with more information than he had. How on earth could he make the decisions, if that is the case? He has also got the hide not to answer these questions.

That is why the Natural Heritage Trust grant approval process stinks. It is not just because Mr Billson flew to South Australia and was in the room when the Victorian grants were dealt with. It is not just because Senator Crane and Senator Eggleston were in the room when the Western Australian grants were determined here in Canberra. It is not just that we have found out that Senator Crane and his family might have some involvement in a project in Western Australia. It is because these clear questions of process go to the administration of Senator Hill's ministerial responsibility and relate to the use or abuse of taxpayers' money in this country. These are important questions that deserve answers.

talk.start.para: —Why did you mislead the Senate?
—This Senate is entitled to an answer on these important issues.
—You couldn't lie straight in bed.
—What we say is that Senator Hill is covering up. What have you got to hide, Senator Hill? What you have got to hide is a massive shonk, a massive rort that rolled up in the Natural Heritage Trust.
—Why are you a liar? Why are you misleading the Senate?
—Senator Campbell, would you please withdraw those comments?
—Which one—that his research officer is as bad as he is, that he is stupid, that he is a liar?
—Withdraw all unparliamentary language.
—Or the one about the dead man voting in left wing ballots of the New South Wales Labor Party?
—Senator Campbell, would you please withdraw all unparliamentary language?
—I withdraw all unparliamentary language about Senator Faulkner.
—Thank you.
—The reason is that this is a rort.

—We have been subjected to the greatest beat-up over this mater that I have seen in the time that I have been in the Senate. Senator Faulkner is misleading the Senate in the most disgraceful way possible. Time and time again he has been shown to be saying things which he knows are not true, beating up information and performing in a disgraceful way.

speech.para: The cold hard facts of this matter are very simple—that is, the money went to where the problems are. The money went to rural areas because that is where the environmental problems are.
