Also, $300,000 has been allocated for an evaluation of those measures.

So you can see we are trying to address the concerns that some senators have raised in this last debate for a relative handful of young people, but an important handful that we want to see are not disadvantaged by the proposals. After all, the majority of young people will be substantially benefited by the requirement and the encouragement that it gives to them and their families to stay in some form of skills acquisition. It is not necessarily school, but it may be school. It has to be some form of skills acquisition if these young people are not going to be long-term disadvantaged, not merely short-term disadvantaged.
Request not agreed to.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6.50 p.m. and there being no discussion on government documents, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to talk about the proposed quarantine changes in Tasmania. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, AQIS, and the Tasmanian state quarantine program are delivered as an integrated service by the quarantine officers employed by the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries. This integrated program is efficient, highly effective and avoids having two separate quarantine systems in Tasmania. The state is reimbursed by the Commonwealth for the costs associated with their delivery of the program. The combined quarantine program of both imports and exports includes plant and animal products and produce, both to and from interstate and overseas.

speech.para: Barrier checks are located at Currie sea and air ports on King Island, Whitemark sea and air ports on Flinders Island, Smithton airport, Wynyard airport, Devonport airport, Launceston airport and Hobart airport. Quarantine centres are located at Burnie, Devonport, Launceston and Hobart, with a post entry quarantine station located at Kingston, south of Hobart.

The Tasmanian quarantine program provides a high level of quarantine security at all these major points of entry into the state. A team of highly trained, multiskilled, efficient quarantine staff and quarantine detector dogs control the entry points. The current arrangement supports and helps to extend Tasmania's clean, fresh and pure image as well as maintain the state's disease-free status.

To maintain Tasmania's disease-free status, the quarantine systems and procedures are subject to both national and international audits. During the past two years, the state's quarantine systems have been audited by AQIS and by Japanese, Chinese and Korean quarantine officials. Additionally, over the past two years, a number of quality assurance programs for interstate imports have been implemented. It takes a considerable time to get a quality assurance system up and running but, in the long term, it is a means of freeing up resources without lowering the level of quarantine security.

The state quarantine legislation is controlled by the state Plant Quarantine Act of 1997. A total of 20 pest and disease surveys are conducted to show that certain pests and diseases just do not occur in Tasmania or, if they do, to indicate at what level they do occur. This is a requirement under the World Trade Organisation—WTO—guidelines. Surveys are undertaken for the existence of fruit fly, codling moth, potato cyst nematode, tobacco blue mould, bacterial wilt and fire blight, among other pests and diseases.

Tasmania has national and international recognition for area freedom status. Currently, there are 12 countries to which Tasmania exports fresh produce under this status. They include the important markets of Japan, Taiwan, China, Philippines and Indonesia. The benefits to Tasmanian producers as a result of area freedom status are currently in excess of $40 million per annum. Products exported under this arrangement include apples, pears, tomatoes, stone fruit, berry fruit, squash, peas and cut flowers.

The area freedom status from fruit fly is also a good example. Once the fruit fly free area freedom status is gained, however, an ongoing program in addition to the barrier control systems is necessary to maintain it, and Tasmania instigated a fruit fly trapping program in order to ensure this status can be maintained.

One of the more recent and successful activities has been the introduction of the quarantine detector dog program for domestic and international arrival of both air and sea passengers. The two teams, located in Hobart and Burnie, have been very well received by the public, and their level of detection has proven to be very good, with approximately 2.5 tonnes of prohibited products detected at the barrier last year. A third detector dog team is scheduled to be introduced during this financial year and will be based at the Launceston airport. The quaint sniffer dogs, which attract so much favourable attention at airports and the Spirit of Tasmania ferry terminal, really are very efficient resources in the fight to enforce quarantine rules.

The level of quarantine activity undertaken at the barrier during 1996-97 included: 1,444 vessels inspected; 8,501 flights inspected; 86.105 tonnes of barrier seizures; 31.795 tonnes of barrier treatments; 118 insect or disease detections; 95,092 containers inspected; 2,234 containers treated; 57,869 postal articles inspected; and 6,262 quarantine entries lodged. And so the list goes on.

I have some concerns that there is currently a move to split the service in two on the misunderstanding that AQIS can carry out the service more cheaply than the combined service currently in operation. Tasmania has a lot and too much to lose. That is the point. A move away from the existing arrangement would have serious ramifications for the Tasmanian quarantine system.

Under the present arrangement, each system, that of AQIS and that of the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries, support each other. To run a stand-alone service would be very expensive, and the level of quarantine security would fall. Tasmanian exporters are understandably extremely concerned and very keen that the quarantine system be kept in Tasmanian hands. Exporters believe that any diversion from the present arrangement could have a negative impact on the state's current and continued development of its disease-free status.

Owing to the state's decentralised shipping system and the decreased volume of throughput traffic in comparison to the mainland states, it would be very difficult for the state of Tasmania to maintain a quarantine and export system of international standard without Commonwealth support. To operate two separate systems in a state the size of Tasmania would be a duplication of activities and result in false economy.

I believe that revised Commonwealth cost estimates may be erroneously based on the high throughputs of mainland states. Any reduction in control and surveillance could result in the highest cost of all: the introduction of new pests and diseases into Tasmania. The risk to Tasmania is too great. The current integrated program must be maintained to ensure the highest level of quarantine security for Australia's best natural asset—the state of Tasmania.

talk.start.para: —Four weeks ago, the federal health minister again granted the Australian Formula One Grand Prix an exemption from the federal government's ban on tobacco advertising. There was no announcement, no fanfare and—I suggest—there was no concern for the health of young people in this country. Let me refer tonight to some statistics on tobacco advertising.

speech.para: The Medical Journal of Australia published the results of its national survey which showed that 27 per cent of men and 23 per cent of women smoked in 1995. That is hardly any change since 1992. These figures compare with places like California where smoking rates have fallen from 25 per cent in 1988 to just 16 per cent in 1992. That was as a result of large-scale advertising campaigns. I think it is fair to say that we have the Labor government to thank for our failure to reduce smoking levels. Spending on educational campaigns dropped from 70 cents per head of population in 1989-1990 to just 25 cents per person in 1995-1996.

Just a few days ago, Professor Simon Chapman pointed out that when the program of legislative action taps began to turn off, the 20-year fall in smoking also levelled off. He said that one year from today about 18,700 Australians who smoke will be dead because of their smoking. That is about 25 per cent more deaths in one year than from breast cancer, melanoma, diabetes, suicide, road deaths, leukemia, cirrhosis of the liver, falls, AIDS, murder, narcotics, drowning and maternal deaths during childbirth combined.

The federal government launched its $7 million campaign, the national Quit campaign, in July last year in recognition that cigarette smoking is still the most important preventable cause of premature death in Australia. It said that it should have a very high priority. In his letter to me, the Minister for Health and Family Services said:

We have long known about the risks associated with tobacco use but recent scientific research has now provided unequivocal proof that every cigarette smoked contributes to health damage and that damage can start very early in a smoker's career.
The minister went on:
Through previous efforts at state and federal levels, smoking rates among adults have been reduced to around 25%—
Not really much to crow about when you compare it with other places—
and the encouraging news is that four out of every five smokers have already tried to do so.
That is, give up smoking. Each sheet accompanying the letter has the slogan `Every cigarette is doing you damage'—as indeed it does.

I have concerns that there is evidence that state governments—and this is certainly the case in New South Wales and Victoria—have already backed off on their spending on anti-smoking campaigns. However, today I want to raise the matter of the federal government's continued insistence that it must grant exemptions from the ban on tobacco advertising for the formula one Grand Prix, the motor cycling grand prix and the local Australian women's golf tournament.

Professor Chapman points out that even though $7 million is going into a Quit campaign, it cannot possibly combat the effects of tobacco advertising in this country. Even though the minister ordered last week that no women in swimsuits be allowed to promote tobacco at the Grand Prix and said that advertising would be reduced from 17 to 14 days, Professor Chapman says that such gestures towards harm reduction are:
. . . the equivalent of removing splinters from the Titanic's handrails: what has been given the green light is an international orgy of tobacco advertising.
He points to the recent advertisements in a tobacco industry trade journal which boasted:
This Formula 1 car is the most powerful advertising space in the world. It will carry your brand to 18 billion TV viewers in 102 countries.

This advertising is, of course, not just confined to television, and I want to talk today about where else this kind of advertising goes. I have a number of documents, the first of which is a copy of a promotional sheet put out by the Australian Grand Prix Corporation some months ago offering corporate packages. Prominent on the front page is a photograph of a formula one car with the unmistakable and clear Marlboro sign in a central position on the page. Overleaf is a portrait of a driver with his hands resting on a helmet where the Rothmans lettering is large and again prominent. In another photograph on the same page there is a car, again with the Rothmans lettering very clear.

On 22 November last year, the Age newspaper featured photographs of cars at the Grand Prix, and again the Rothmans and Marlboro cars enjoy a very central and prominent place where the lettering is remarkably clear. On 29 December, the Age in its Monday motor sports section featured a large photograph of Jacques Villeneuve and his helmet, again with Rothmans lettering, this time measuring some 12 centimetres in width on the page. I picked up a copy of the F1 racing magazine which has no less than 52 separate photographs—that is one in every three pages—featuring advertising for tobacco companies, all made possible through advertising at grand prix. Qantas, one of the sponsors of the Grand Prix, featured a three-page article in its Qantas Club magazine in February and, predictably, Marlboro and Rothmans lettering is very prominent in both photographs used in that article.

I would very much like to know how much Marlboro and Rothmans paid for this kind of advertising. It is very hard to believe that it is a coincidence that the cars used featured tobacco advertising rather than featuring other sponsors such as CSR, Mobil or Canon, to name just a few. I have chosen a very small sample of the way in which tobacco companies are not just advertising on the track—as if that was not bad enough. But advertising is now reaching a very wide audience and exploiting to the hilt that very small window of opportunity which the federal government has given it.

The Grand Prix is a very attractive event to young people—it is glamorous, it is about risk taking. The patrons at the Grand Prix are predominantly male and they are predominantly young. Tobacco advertising at one of our most prominent sporting events is happening because this government, like others before it, has buckled under pressure from tobacco companies. I have to say that we can only presume this is because they are contri butors to both the Liberal and the ALP coffers.

As I understand it, the minister is required to assure him- or herself that failure to exempt the Grand Prix would lose the race for Australia. There are plenty of Melburnians who would not be too worried about that prospect, and there are many more who, like me, believe it has absolutely no place in a park. However, I think there is increasing evidence to show that Australia would not lose the race. I think we need to ask some very hard questions about why it is that even higher profile events are not targeted by tobacco companies for sponsorship. International cricket, rugby league and the Australian Open tennis are all pretty obvious examples. Belgium recently indicated that it will not allow tobacco advertising. In the UK, alternative sponsors are being found for their formula one teams.

I look forward to the minister's response to questions that I have put on notice which actually go to that question. I look forward to understanding why the government is so willing to put at risk young lives and to take one step forward and two steps back, as it were, in the fight against tobacco use in this country. I look forward to the government again justifying its sell-out of the future health of our young people.

talk.start.para: —I rise to say a few words about one of Australia's leading young, brilliant poets, John Forbes. John Forbes passed away in January. In a short period of only 47 years, John stamped himself as one of Australia's great poets. An obituary in the Sunday Age of 1 February said:

speech.para: The death at 47 of John Forbes has taken from the Australian literary world one of its most brilliant, accomplished and well-regarded poets. John came to prominence at an early age as part of the generation of `68, those writers who opened up Australian poetry to international currents of post-modern poetics, and from then on had a central position despite his relatively small output.

It is a poetry of wit and intellectual rigor in which a Pop Art sensibility strikes sparks off philosophical themes and where an overarching concern with form and ideas never collapses in on itself but breathes with everydayness, with politics and humour, colloquial language and colloquial subject matter.

It was my great privilege to have attended school with John Forbes at Cronulla De La Salle College in the late 1960s, and also to have studied English literature with him at the University of Sydney. John was a year ahead of me at school. I, and many of my friends and colleagues, both at school and subsequently at university, owe a great debt of gratitude to him.

I recall that, when I was at school, John was already stamping himself as a person of incredible intellect, a person who could argue about the issues of the Vietnam War—which was a matter of great concern to young people of my generation—and at the same time quote Latin poets and philosophers. He had an incredible intellectual range and capacity. He was a passionate student of English, history—including military history—the classics and the fine arts.

One of his former schoolteachers, Brother Quentin, in an obituary in the Sydney Morning Herald, also remembered John as a brilliant and passionate student in English and history, who was sensitive, creative and articulate, with a great love of literature. Brother Quentin said:
He was very forthright, and challenged me on the churches stand on the Vietnam War when other boys would talk to you about the football or the races.

John's reputation as one of Australia's leading poets has been referred to in many of the articles written since his sudden and untimely death on 23 January. People such as David Malouf, John Tranter, Carl Harrison Ford and Don Anderson from the University of Sydney, and other notable people in Australian literary circles have praised John for his brilliance as a poet, his innovativeness and his warmth. He was a great human being. He was a person who lived life to the full but who, unfortunately, was taken much earlier than we would have wished, when he certainly had years of promise and writing before him.
John wrote to me when I was appointed to this parliament in May 1994. I had not seen him for 15 years as he had moved to Mel bourne and our paths had not crossed. In his letter he said:
Dear Mick,
Though our paths haven't crossed for 15 years or so, I thought I'd send you the enclosed by way of congratulations on your elevation to the Senate. I hope you enjoy it.
He had sent me a copy of his latest publication of poems, New and Selected Poems by John Forbes , which was in the Angus & Robertson series, Modern Poets. He went on in the letter to say:

Some of these poems are directly political—"The Numbers" (self-explanatory), "Watching the Treasurer" (a portrait of the PM, circa 1987) and "Afternoon Papers" (my idea of how a right wing social democrat sees things on a good day—I was thinking of Wran when I wrote it). But I hope you enjoy the rest of them as well.
Yours,
John Forbes
On the inside of the collection that he sent to me he inscribed the words:
Mick, didn't our school produce left-wingers? Cheers, John Forbes.

I read the poems and then I wrote back to him, telling him that I had spent many years after my honours degree in English literature at Sydney University—which I did along with John, although I was a year behind him—in the union movement and reading law reports, and I had not had much time for literature. I hoped that I would get some respite in the Senate and be able to return to what was a great love of my life, just as it was John's. Sadly, I have not done as much reading as I had hoped and the opportunity did not arise to meet up with John again. I am saddened by not having had the opportunity to meet him before his untimely passing.

I take this opportunity to put on the record not only my good fortune in having been a friend of John's, but also to recognise the contribution of somebody whose work will live on in Australian literature; someone who made a difference. I would like to quote some words from his poem Watching the Treasurer. I will not quote the whole poem, because I do not think Paul Keating, whom I also count as a friend, would necesarily appreciate it. When describing watching Paul Keating, who was then Treasurer, on television, John wrote `Paul Keating's bottom lip trembles then recovers, like the exchange rate under pressure'. John had a remarkable vision; he could see things that many of us perhaps do not often see.

To his parents, Leonard and Phyllis, to his brothers Michael, Chris and Greg, I say that it was a sad time when I heard about the passing of John. I extend to them my sympathies. As I said earlier, Australia and Australian literature is all the greater for having had John Forbes as one of our poets. He left his mark on our society.

talk.start.para: —Honourable senators will have heard about the measures that have been introduced by Senator Hill and the Commonwealth and Queensland governments to protect the endangered animal sea cow, the dugong. Senators will know that Senator Hill has done a lot of work in putting together a plan to protect this species. Most senators will probably be aware that the threats to the dugong in the southern Great Barrier Reef region have been identified as incidental capture in commercial fishing nets, boat strikes, bather safety shark nets, coastal impact and indigenous hunting.

speech.para: Madam Deputy President, you may be aware that for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people dugong are not only harvested as a food source but are an important species for cultural ceremonies and events. The species is an integral part of their culture. It was for this reason that I was very pleased, on Thursday, 19 February, to be able to launch the Kuku Yalanji conservation and management plan for the green sea turtle and the dugong. The Kuku Yalanji community are traditional inhabitants of the Mossman and Daintree area of Far North Queensland. The launch of the management plan took place at their community centre located at the Mossman Gorge.

The launch of the plan was a quite historic step in the development of community based initiatives for the protection of endangered species within the Great Barrier Reef region. The initiative contributes to the global protection of these species for future generations. The results of surveys commissioned by the Commonwealth government through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority since the middle of 1996 show that a significant decline of between 50 and 80 per cent has occurred in dugong numbers in that southern Great Barrier Reef region. These animals are now considered critically endangered within that area.

It is recognised by the Commonwealth and the Queensland governments that the dugong and turtle are under threat, particularly dugong. As I mentioned, through the vehicle of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council, a number of measures have been implemented to protect the remaining dugong numbers from threat. One of the most difficult of these has been the setting up of particular dugong protection zones where commercial net fishing is not possible. It was interesting that the Aboriginal communities of North Queensland had got together to do their own management plan and, by their own laws and their own efforts, to ensure that no dugong were taken in the sea areas in which the Kuku Yalanji people have traditional ownership.

The Kuku Yalanji people were encouraged by the two governments, through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, to set up their plan. They have developed this community based conservation plan and have demonstrated that the will of a few people can become the actions of the whole community. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Queensland Department of Environment helped those people to develop their management plan for dugong and turtle. It has really been a great example of how indigenous people can empower themselves and their community.

Their plan arose from the Aboriginal marine ranger training program which was established in response to a need identified by indigenous communities for training of indigenous and non-indigenous marine and coastal management techniques. The program was established by staff of the Queensland Department of Environment. The establishment of this training plan was closely linked to a project funded by GRBMPA. It was a community based Low Isles preservation society which was participating in the management of Low Isles, a site of a recently decommissioned lighthouse.

Funds were provided to employ two rangers, which was an ideal opportunity to involve traditional custodians in marine park management. However, the traditional custodians felt they lacked the necessary skills and experience to work as rangers. Therefore, this ranger training program was developed. It was first done in the Port Douglas and Mossman area. It was really out of this training program that this conservation and management plan arose.

The launch which I attended was a very happy and successful affair. We were treated to some traditional dance performances by members of the Kuku Yalanji community and the dances were very colourful. They told the story of the traditional hunting of the crocodile and the turtle.

Following that, we had a quite spectacular lunch prepared by the Kuku Yalanji people. It was only after I had finished eating and inquired what the type of stew was that I had partaken of that I found that it included some green sea turtle meat. Whilst the management plan and the Kuku Yalanji people themselves have imposed a moratorium on dugong hunting, with the green sea turtle, which is not quite as endangered, they have put in place a very strict permit system whereby community people can, once each year, get a permit to take a green sea turtle.

The ceremony, as I say, was quite a colourful one. After that, I was taken by some of the Kuku Yalanji people into the rainforest where they were able to explain the importance of that area and of the various plants and flora to their community.

Following lunch, we were taken by the community on a tour of some of the offshore areas where the management plan will be implemented. The plan, from its development to its operation, has led to an increase in employment and training opportunities and, as I mentioned, Kuku Yalanji people are now being employed by the Queensland Department of Environment as community rangers.

Other outcomes from this process have been the identification of additional projects such as seagrass monitoring and the development of cultural heritage management programs with the Queensland Department of Environment.

The government is very keen to use this project as an example in a pilot to show what other indigenous communities can do along the Queensland coast. We are very confident that, with the assistance of ATSIC, all of the Aboriginal communities along the southern Great Barrier Reef will put in place these management plans so that the dugong will be saved from being taken by indigenous people doing their traditional hunting. That is good news for the dugong, of course, and very good news for the Queensland and Commonwealth governments in their campaign to protect this species.

The Kuku Yalanji people put a lot of effort into their plan. They are to be congratulated on this very significant event, on the work they have done on it and on the way they have honoured it and put it together. It is really a great credit to that community that they have put this plan together. On behalf of the government, I thank them very much for what they have done and for the tremendous work they are doing in the conservation of this very rare species.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Treasury: Public Relations Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 816)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 September 1997:

question.para: (1) What contracts for public relations services has the department, or its agencies, signed since
3 March 1996.
(2) What was the value of each contract.
(3) Did the value of any contract vary from the original cost; if so, what was the reason for the price variation.
(4) How many of the contracts in (1) were awarded following an open tender process.
(5) Where there was no tender process, what assessment criteria were followed in selecting the contractor and why was the normal practice of calling tenders not followed.
(6) Did the department seek guidance from the Office of Government Information and Advertising before signing the above contracts; if not, why not.
(7) How many journalists were employed by the department as at 3 March 1996.
(8) How many journalists are currently employed by the department.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The information sought is provided for each agency in the portfolio.
Treasury Department
No contracts have been signed by the Department of the Treasury for public relations services since 3 March 1996, nor has the Department employed any journalists at, or since, that date.
Industry Commission
No contracts have been signed by the Industry Commission for public relations services since 3 March 1996, nor has the Commission employed any journalists at, or since, that date.
Insurance and Superannuation Commission
No contracts have been signed by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission for public relations services since 3 March 1996, nor has the Commission employed any journalists at, or since, that date.
Royal Australian Mint
No contracts have been signed by the Royal Australian Mint for public relations services since 3 March 1996, nor has the Mint employed any journalists at, or since, that date.
National Competition Council
No contracts have been signed by the National Competition Council for public relations services since 3 March 1996, nor has the Council employed any journalists at, or since, that date.
Australian Securities Commission

Since 3 March 1996 the Australian Securities Commission has signed one contract for public relations services. The contract is with Hill & Knowlton Australia Pty Ltd at a cost of $250 per hour, with the cost-to-date being $6,000. The work performed under the contract has not varied from the original cost. A limited tender process was undertaken and potential contractors were approached within DoFA procurement guidelines. Based on internal knowledge of the industry and the market three potential contractors were invited to provide quotes for the service required. As there was a tight timeframe, OGIA was not consulted. At 3 March 1996 two journalists were employed by the ASC, one as a Media Adviser and one as a Public Affairs Officer. The ASC currently employs one journalist as a Media Adviser.
Australian Competition & Consumer Commission

No contracts for public relations services have been signed since 3 March 1996. At 3 March 1996 one journalist was employed by the ACCC as a Public Affairs Officers. The ACCC currently employs one journalist as a Public Affairs Officers.
Australian Bureau of Statistics

Since 3 March 1996 the ABS has signed two contracts for public relations services. One contract was with SG Communications with a value of $34,000; and the other was with Professional Public Relations with a value of $28,900. The value of the latter contract was less than the original cost as the ABS did not use all of the options covered by the contract. A limited tender process was undertaken in both cases and potential contractors were approached within DOFA procurement guidelines. The low costs involved and the purpose of the services did not require OGIA involvement. At 3 March 1996 three journalists were employed by ABS as Public Affairs Officers. The ABS currently employs three journalists as Public Affairs Officers.
Reserve Bank of Australia

Since 3 March 1996 the Reserve Bank has signed one contract for public relations services. The contract was with Javelin Public Relations Ltd with a value of $1,800. The final value of the contract was higher than the original cost as additional services were requested under the contract. A limited tender process was undertaken. Based on internal knowledge of the industry and the market only two potential contractors were invited to provide quotes for the service required. OGIA was not consulted, as the value of the contract was very low and there was a tight timeframe. The Bank did not have any journalists employed at 3 March 1996, nor are any journalists currently employed by the Bank.
Australian Taxation Office

Since 3 March 1996 the ATO has signed two contracts for public relations services. One contract was with Cosway Creative Communication with a value of $60,000; and the other was with Burson-Marstellar with a final value of $93,753. The value of the latter contract was less than the original cost as the ATO did not use all of the services covered by the contract. The Cosway contract was awarded following an open tender process. Because of short timeframes a limited tender process was undertaken for the Burson-Marstellar. OGIA provided guidance for both processes. The ATO did not have any journalists employed at 3 March 1996, nor are any journalists currently employed by the ATO.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Treasury: Salary Packaging
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 836)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Has the department negotiated or indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.
(2) Has the department informed any staff of its intention to offer salary packaging schemes to its employees.
(3) Can a copy be provided of the communication in (2), as well as information regarding: (a) when it took place; and (b) what developments have occurred regarding implementation of salary packaging.
(4) Can details be provided of any salary packaging arrangements which have been made available to employees of the department.
(5) Can details be provided of the number of salary packaging arrangements which have been entered into by employees.

(6) (a) Are salary packaging arrangements being offered to all employees or only selected employees; (b) if selected employees, what class of employee is being offered salary packaging; and (c) what are the salary ranges applicable to these employees.
(7) What percentage of an employee's total salary is allowed to be taken as non-salary benefits.
(8) Please list the options or items that are allowed to be salary packaged under any department arrangement.
(9) Do any of the arrangements offered benefit from an employer exemption from fringe benefits tax.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The department has indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.
(2) Yes.
(3) At a departmental seminar on 20 June 1997, the Secretary to the Treasury said:

". . . .. salary packaging will be generally available, within the parameters determined by the Government and within a policy to be developed by management that will not allow packaging with tax aggressive elements".

On 6 November 1997, the Secretary to the Treasury distributed to Treasury staff a draft Certified Agreement and explanatory information. The following paragraph is the section of the Treasury draft Certified Agreement that deals with proposed salary repackaging arrangements:
3.4 Flexible Remuneration Packaging

All Treasury employees will have access to flexible remuneration packaging, in accordance with policies approved by the Secretary, and as varied from time to time, provided that any additional costs incurred by the Treasury are met by the employee.
The following paragraph is the section of the explanatory notes to the Treasury draft Certified Agreement that deals with proposed salary repackaging arrangements:
Flexible remuneration packaging

Treasury employees will be able to sacrifice part of their salary in return for non-cash benefits. It is currently envisaged that the `menu' of options will include fees and subscriptions to professional associations, payment of home office expenses, payment of self-education expenses, financial counselling fees, contributions to a private superan nuation fund, motor vehicles (under a novated lease), computer software used in an officer's employment, notebook and laptop computers, some other work-related items and payment of health and disability income protection insurance premiums. Other benefits that are fully subject to Fringe Benefits Tax will not be available.

A consultant will be engaged to help develop a Departmental policy on remuneration packaging and possibly to administer the arrangements. In line with Government policy on this issue, employees who choose to sacrifice salary will bear the cost of its administration (currently, approximately $300 per person annually)

In early December 1997, a summary document `Main Points of Policy on Remuneration Packaging' was distributed to Treasury staff as part of the negotiation process over the draft Certified Agreement—a copy of that document is attached.

On 11 February 1998, the Secretary to the Treasury formally proposed a Certified Agreement to Treasury staff. The following paragraph is the section of the Treasury Certified Agreement that deals with proposed salary repackaging arrangements:
3.4 Flexible Remuneration Packaging

All Treasury employees will have access to flexible remuneration packaging, in accordance with Government policies, provided that any additional costs incurred by the Treasury are met by the employee. Guidelines for remuneration packaging will be prepared and finalised as soon as possible during the life of this Agreement.
The following is the section of the explanatory notes on the Treasury Certified Agreement that deals with proposed salary repackaging arrangements:
Flexible remuneration packaging

Treasury employees will be able to sacrifice part of their salary in return for non-cash benefits. It is currently envisaged that the `menu' of options will include fees and subscriptions to professional associations, payment of home office expenses, payment of self-education expenses, financial counselling fees, contributions to a private superannuation fund, motor vehicles (under a novated lease), computer software used in an officer's employment, notebook and laptop computers, some other work-related items and payment of health and disability income protection insurance premiums. Other benefits that are fully subject to Fringe Benefits Tax will not be available.

A consultant has been engaged to help develop a Departmental policy on remuneration packaging as soon as possible after certification of the Agreement. A consultant will also administer the arrangements. In line with Government policy on this issue, employees who choose to sacrifice salary will bear the cost of its administration (currently, approximately $300 per person annually).

Implementation of salary packaging is at an early stage. As noted above, a consultant has been engaged to help develop a Departmental policy on remuneration packaging, but there have been no other developments.

(4) No salary packaging arrangements have been made available to employees of the department at this stage, other than those already made available to staff under, for example, the Executive Vehicle Scheme.
(6) (a) As noted above, the Secretary to the Treasury has indicated that salary packaging arrangements will be generally available.
(b) N/A.
(c) N/A.

(7) Access to salary packaging by Treasury employees is to be limited to a range of packaging options rather than by imposing a limit on the percentage of an employee's total salary that can be taken as non-salary benefits.
(8) Please see the attached document `Main Points of Policy on Remuneration Packaging'.

(9) No. In general, Australian Public Service employers are required to pay fringe benefits tax on benefits provided to employees due to the operation of the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986.
MAIN POINTS OF POLICY ON REMUNERATION PACKAGING
. Remuneration packaging is to be available to all Treasury staff.
. Treasury will engage a consultant to administer remuneration packaging for Treasury employees.
. Remuneration packaging must occur at no direct cost to the employer—this is a government requirement for APS agencies.
- All administrative fees must therefore be borne by the employee—the consultant currently charges $275 per year per employee.
- If Treasury is liable to pay increased fringe benefits tax or other taxes as a result of these arrangements, those costs will also be passed onto the employee.

. Salary available for packaging will be defined as the employee's base salary specified in the relevant Certified Agreement or Australian Workplace Agreement. It does not include variable or occasional payments, such as allowances.
- If a bonus is paid, the employee will be able to elect to take all of the bonus in the form of one or more package items or all in cash.
- Salary for superannuation purposes will continue to be that prescribed in the relevant Certified Agreement or Australian Workplace Agreement.
. Remuneration packaging will only be available to employees who have produced evidence that they have received independent financial advice.
- If this condition is not imposed, the consultant's administration fee would be considerably higher.
- The consultant will train and accredit a panel of consultants who can provide such advice.
. Other than in exceptional circumstances, an employee's remuneration package can only be reviewed once every twelve months.
. Remuneration packaging arrangements will not necessarily be portable to any other employer.
. The following items will be available to employees for inclusion in their remuneration package:
- FBT not payable (if substantiated via otherwise deductible rule):
: membership fees and subscriptions to professional associations;
: work-related home office expenses;
: financial counselling fees and remuneration packaging administration charge;
: disability/income protection insurance premiums;
: self education expenses (work related, excludes HECS payments);
: work related travel expenses not met by Treasury;
- concessionally taxed or not subject to FBT/not classified as a fringe benefit:

: motor vehicle for private use, by way of a novated lease—the vehicle must be new or up to three years old, have a purchase price/lease value not exceeding $55,000 and be manufactured or assembled in Australia; operating costs of a vehicle under a novated lease can also be packaged; under Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business guidelines, this item will not be available to SES officers who have received cash in lieu of a Commonwealth vehicle;
: mobile phones for predominantly business use;
: personal computers (notebook and laptop only, limit of one per year);
: computer software used in the employee's employment;
: contributions to a private superannuation fund;
- subject to FBT:
: health insurance premiums.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister explain why: (a) foreign economic aid spending is down $335.9 million from 1995-96 to 1996-97; and (b) there is a $129.5 million difference between the amount spent to 30 June 1997 and the budget estimate.
(2) What are the `underspends' in the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio referred to in the Final Budget Outcome.
(3) Is the Government going to increase its actual commitment to funding foreign economic aid in the 1998-99 budget estimates.
(4) Does the Government acknowledge Australia is being criticised because of the lowering of Australia's commitment in providing foreign economic aid.
(5) Does the Government believe Australia's bilateral or multilateral relations will be negatively affected as a result of Australia's lowered spending in foreign overseas aid.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Foreign Economic Aid function as reported in Final Budget Outcome 1996-97 is a classification used by the Department of Finance and Administration and based on the International Monetary Fund's A Manual on Government Finance Statistics and the United Nations' System of National Accounts. This function includes Official Development Assistance (ODA) as well as other international outlays including contributions to the activities of international organisations and United Nations peacekeeping operations.

(a) ODA declined by $160 million from 1995-96 to 1996-97, largely due to the termination of the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) ($114.9 million) and reductions in contributions to some international organisations and program assistance. The reduction in Australia's overseas aid program in 1996-97 reflected Australia's reduced capacity to provide assistance due to the need to address the budget deficit. In addition, non-ODA outlays declined by $175.9 million which included underspending in planned contributions to UN peacekeeping operations and declining general non-aid administration costs, largely due to $96.2 million of miscellaneous receipts to the Overseas Property Group (DAS). A one-off, non-ODA, loan payment was also provided to Papua New Guinea in 1995-96.

(b) ODA outlays in 1996-97 were $2.947 million lower than the 1996-97 budget estimate including $2.1 million under expenditure in running costs. Non-ODA outlays were $126.55 million lower than the 1996-97 budget estimate largely due to underspending in planned contributions to UN peacekeeping operations and declines in general non-aid administration.

(2) `Underspends' in the Foreign Affairs and Trade Portfolio for 1996-97 included running costs ($21.5 million), Capital Works and Services ($2.4 million), PNG Australian Staffing Assistance Group ($0.6 million), DIFF ($0.27 million), Australia-Japan Foundation ($0.26 million) and International Organisations ($0.07 million).
(3) The level of funding for Australia's ODA in 1998-99 will be determined in the budget process.

(4) Some partner governments have expressed regret at the reduction in Australia's development assistance. At the same time, most foreign governments accept the Australian Government's sovereign right to determine its own economic priorities and understand the fiscal imperatives which led to the reduced aid budget. In volume terms, Australia remains above the average of OECD aid donor nations.

(5) Naturally there has been some disappointment and concern expressed by partner governments and multilateral development agencies affected by the reductions. Nonetheless, Australia's relationships with aid partners are strong and extend across a broad front—covering a wide range of political, security and economic issues in the global, regional and bilateral arenas. In the multilateral sphere, Australia continues to contribute significantly to a wide range of multilateral efforts.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 26 November 1997:

question.para: (1) In what condition is the phone line to Warburton, Western Australia, and surrounds.
(2) Is it a fact that at times the phone line does not work at all.
(3) Is it a fact that the phone line does not allow for data transmission.
(4) Is Telstra of the view that the phone line needs to be upgraded.
(5) Is the Minister of the view that services need to be upgraded.

(6) Was the coordinator of the Nganyatjarra Council, Mr Peter Rapkins, promised in July 1997 that the digital radio concentrator system was to be replaced by optical fibre cable; if so: (a) were any conditions placed on this promise; and (b) what were the conditions.
(7) Why was Mr Rapkins told in August 1997 that this was not going to occur.
(8) Does Telstra currently have plans to upgrade services to Warburton; if so, when is this due to occur.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice provided by Telstra, is as follows:

answer.para: (1 and 2) Telstra advises that Warburton is one of the most remote communities in Australia serviced by Telstra. Whilst the service is maintained to standards consistent with requirements under Telstra's Universal Service Obligation (USO), there are occasional breakdowns on the Digital Radio Concentrator Service (DRCS) serving the community which take time to restore due to the remoteness of the area.

An increase in the number of calls being made by customers has led to the capacity of the system to handle calls being exceeded from time to time. Telstra advises that it has acted to relieve congestion by the provision of a satellite based service to Warburton on 12 December 1997. Telstra will transfer customers from the DRCS to the satellite service, which Telstra expects will result in greatly improved performance to Warburton and surrounding areas.
(3) Telstra advises that the system in place prior to 12 December 1997 allows data transmission at 2400 bps modulated using the standard telephone service.
(4) Refer to the answer to questions 1 & 2 above.

(5) Telstra has a universal service obligation (USO) to provide all Australians with reasonable access to standard telephone services, payphones and prescribed carriage services on an equitable basis. The precise manner in which it complies with this obligation is a matter for Telstra to determine, subject to oversight from the Australian Communications Authority. As a Government business enterprise, Telstra provides services on a commercial basis, and must make its own commercial and management decisions within the context of legislative requirements and Government policies.

Telstra has advised that it has acted to relieve congestion of the Digital Radio Concentrator Service (DRCS) serving the Warburton community by the provision of a satellite based service to Warburton on 12 December 1997. Telstra will transfer customers from the DRCS to the satellite service, which is expected to result in greatly improved performance to Warburton and surrounding areas. Also, refer to the answers to questions 1 & 2 above.

(6) Telstra advises that it wrote to Mr Rapkins in November 1996 indicating that a solution to the degraded service being experience by Warburton and other Aboriginal Communities was to replace the DRCS by providing an optical fibre backbone system from Amata to Blackstone and replacing the DRCS from Blackstone with a Very High Capacity Radio Concentrator (VHCRC) service. Project timing was given as 1998/99. Short term relief was to be provided by an ITERRA satellite solution at Warburton. The letter contained the following conditions: "Assuming that funding is available, it should be noted that undertaking upgrading using cable will be dependent on Telstra being given clearance to plough cable on the Amata to Blackstone route".

(7) Telstra advises that, in meeting its Universal Service Obligation, it must have regard to provisioning costs, and the reliability of equipment. The choice of technology to meet these requirements is under continuous review, and in a rapidly changing technological environment, the solution to any requirement can change before implementation. An in-depth review of the options for the Warburton area is currently being carried out; options include the use of optic fibre, radio and satellite technologies. Early indications are that solutions other than fibre will be more cost effective and will meet the appropriate operational criteria.

(8) Telstra advises that, as mentioned above, Telstra upgraded services to the Warburton area on 12 December 1997 by the provision of a satellite service. Telstra is currently reviewing the options to provide longer term solutions, with the completion of the project expected by June 1999. However, factors such as the availability of equipment from overseas manufacturers and the provision of land access clearances may impact on this time frame.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (1) What information has been received on the preparation of multiple Telstra share applications or the sale of Telstra shares to bogus names.

(2) What would be the legal implications of a share investor who sold instalment receipts under bogus names and then utilised a trust account operated by stockbrokers or solicitors to disguise profits.
(3) Could investors who obtained shares under bogus names transfer shares into a real owner's name by lodging a share transfer form with the Share Registry.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Public Offer Document for the Telstra Sale stated (at the bottom of page 8) that the Commonwealth reserved the right to reject or aggregate applications that appeared to be multiple applications from the same person. That right was exercised by subjecting multiple share applications to de-duplication during the application processing stage.
There is no information on whether, or how many, Telstra shares were sold to people using `bogus names'.
(2) The legal implications would depend upon the specific circumstances of any case, and no general answer can be provided.

To sell Telstra Instalment Receipts (IRs) an investor would, in the usual case, have to open an account with a stockbroker. To open an account, the investor would generally need to provide some form of identification. This may eliminate many `bogus names', or at least make it difficult for them to sell the IRs easily.
If an investor `disguised profits' for the purpose of lowering taxable income, an offence would be committed under Australia's taxation legislation.

(3) Provided share transfer forms are properly executed, which in the case of a transfer from one name to another requires signatures by both parties and payment of stamp duty, there is no obligation upon the Share Registry to identify the bona fides of the two parties to a transfer.

Senator Minchin
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

During the Constitutional Convention election, the AEC conducted a special remote area information program in Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Computer Equipment
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1038)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 1997:

question.para: (1) What were the circumstances surrounding the decision by the department to dispose of surplus computer equipment from approximately 300 departmental office sites around Australia.
(2) What are the relevant Commonwealth procurement guidelines that would apply to such a disposal.
(3) Was the contract advertised; if so, when and in which newspapers/periodicals, et cetera; if not, why not.

(4) (a) What type of tendering arrangement was conducted for the contract; (b) is there a Commonwealth register of firms interested in the purchase of second-hand government computer equipment; and (c) how many names are on the register.

(5) (a) Was a short-list of potential vendors developed; (b) from where were the names drawn; (c) what was the criteria used to select the short list; (d) how many firms were short-listed; and (e) which firms were shortlisted.

(6) (a) Were all the short-listed firms approached to tender; (b) how many tenders were received; (c) what were the names of the firms that submitted tenders; (d) what process was used to evaluate the tenders and select the successful bid; and (e) which firm was ultimately selected.

(7) (a) Under the contract for the removal and sale of departmental second-hand computers, what will be the cost to the department for the removal and disposal of the equipment; (b) what will be the average cost to the vendor for each of the serviceable HP4 laser printers and for each of the personal computers; (c) what will be the cost to the successful vendor for the purchase of the second-hand equipment; (d) what is the anticipated final net cost to the Commonwealth for the settlement of the contract; and (e) what is the agreed timeframe for the completion of the contract.

(8) (a) How are decisions made by the department and the successful vendor as to which equipment is serviceable and therefore chargeable to the vendor; (b) is the department satisfied that no equipment classified as unserviceable is being resold by the vendor;(c) would such resales be inconsistent with the terms of the contract; (d) is the department satisfied that no equipment removed but not purchased by the vendor is being resold by the vendor; and (e)would such resales be inconsistent with the terms of the contract.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department is installing new PC computer platforms in 289 CES offices throughout Australia to support the new employment systems. This project also involves the disposal of the old system's mainframe terminal equipment (7,100 items), and obsolete PCs (800 items) and laser printers (400 items).

During the contract negotiations with IBM Australia for the supply and installation of the new equipment, they quoted a very substantial cost to the Department to remove and dispose of the obsolete equipment. Because DEETYA officers considered the price of disposal to be too expensive, the market was tested by seeking quotations from four other companies (three IT brokers and a manufacturer) to ascertain the feasibility of handling this aspect of the project separately and at a lower cost. Two of the four companies approached responded with quotations which were evaluated together with the IBM Australia quote.

(2) The Department of Administrative Services published guidelines for the disposal of assets in the "IT Buyers' Handbook" in November 1991, and the "Guidelines for Surplus Asset Disposal" in January 1992. The entire disposal process including the approach to three IT brokers, was consistent with those guidelines.

(3) The equipment for disposal was not advertised separately for sale, because its sale could not be separated from its removal from 289 locations. The entire disposal project was awarded on the basis of a competitive process.

(4) (a) In addition to IBM Australia, four companies were identified as having an interest in the obsolete equipment. Of those four, three were identified as brokers of second-hand computers and the other was Memorex Telex, the manufacturer of the obsolete mainframe terminal equipment. All four received a Request for Quotation (RFQ).

(b) Yes. This list is now maintained by the Department of Finance and Administration. It is used by the Aussales group in arranging disposals on behalf of agencies. It is not available to agencies undertaking their own disposals. The Department of Administrative Services was however, consulted on the selection of the winning vendor.

(c) It is believed that around 100 IT dealers are listed, of which only a very few would be brokers interested in removing and disposing of mainframe terminal equipment located 289 locations throughout Australia.
(5) (a) All four vendors were asked to quote.
(b) The three companies were all that were identified as brokers in second-hand computers from a search of a national telephone directory listing of over one million businesses.
(c) All four vendors were asked to provide a quotation. No short-list was prepared.
(d) See 5(c) above.
(e) See 5(c) above. The RFQ was sent to: National Capital Traders; Camray Holdings; HMR Group of Companies; and Memorex Telex.
(6) (a) See 5 (c) above
(b) Two quotations were received in response to the RFQ.
(c) Quotations were provided by: National Capital Traders; and HMR Group of Companies.
Note: These were considered together with the original quote from IBM Australia.
(d) The lowest cost to the Department and the ability of the vendor to carry out the task, were the primary criteria.

(e) National Capital Traders. They offered the lowest cost, and had strong references from the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Social Security for similar work in those organisations.
(7) (a) This information is commercial-in-confidence.
(b) This information is commercial-in-confidence.
(c) This information is commercial-in-confidence.
(d) National Capital Traders will complete the disposal at no cost, and will potentially return a modest sum, to the Department. The other two quotes involved substantial costs to the Department.
(e) The Department expects to complete the project including the settlement negotiations, by the end of January 1998.
(8) (a) The cost of removal of the obsolete equipment will be offset by the average prices tendered by the vendor for the equipment regardless of its condition.
(b) The obsolete equipment was not classified by the Department.
(c) No.

(d) The contract requires the vendor to remove and dispose of all of the obsolete equipment. Any market opportunities for the equipment would have been considered by the vendor in framing the tender which involved the least cost to the Department, when compared with the competition.
(e) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 10 December 1997:

question.para: Following the signing of the Regional Forest Agreement with Tasmania, what remaining rights or obligations does the Federal Government have concerning Tasmania's forests and timber resources.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) is a comprehensive document which will govern the ongoing rights and obligations of both parties. The RFA specifies the actions which the Tasmanian Government must perform to implement its commitments in relation to establishing a comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system, achieving ecologically sustainable forest management and facilitating industry development. A failure to meet these commitments, for example a persistent failure to take the necessary actions to establish and manage new reserves as required under the RFA, could amount to a breach of the RFA. In such a situation, the avenues for dispute resolution which are available to the Commonwealth to seek to address the failure are set out in clauses 11 to 15 of the agreement.
The RFA contains Commonwealth obligations including the following.
Clauses 22, 23. Introduction of legislation—the Commonwealth is obliged to use its best endeavours to secure the enactment of legislation with provisions to the effect that, where an RFA is in force,
(a) the Commonwealth will not impose export controls on woodchips or unprocessed wood from that region
(b) specific Commonwealth legislative provisions will not apply to forestry operations on land which, under the RFA may be used for such operations
(c) the RFA may only be terminated in specified circumstances.
Clause 95. Compensation—the Commonwealth will pay compensation to specified parties if it acts inconsistently with any provision of the RFA and this results in a loss to those parties.
Clause 100, 101. Financial assistance—the Commonwealth will provide financial assistance to Tasmania for the purpose of implementing specified initiatives under the agreement.
Both parties also have ongoing responsibilities in relation to threatened and endangered communities and species, monitoring and review of the agreement, and reporting.

However, no decision to adopt such technology has been made by either the Department or Centrelink.

(3) The Department believes it appropriate to investigate the relevance and suitability of smartcard technology to improve service delivery and security and offer greater choice for customers in the way they access Government programs.

(5) Investigation of the potential for smartcard use will include full public consultation including with peak bodies, community and special interest groups with a particular focus on the privacy implications.
