subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1050)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 19 December 1997.

question.para: (1) Has the Federal Government conducted any market research on community attitudes to reconciliation issues, or any other issues, related to Aboriginal affairs since study no. 9653 by Brian Sweeney and Associates in June 1996; if so, (a) what research has been conducted; (b) by whom; (c) when was the research conducted; and (d) can copies of the research be provided.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No public opinion research on reconciliation or other issues has been undertaken either by ATSIC or by the Reconciliation Branch of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, since the work by Brian Sweeney and Associates in 1996.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 19 December 1997:

question.para: (1) How many times has the Inter-departmental committee which was established by the Government to advise on its official response to the report, "Bringing them Home", met.
(2) Which departments or statutory authorities were represented on the committee.
(3) Was any advice from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission on a suggested Government response to the report sought, independent of that provided by the Inter-departmental committee.

(4) Were any discussions sought with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Board of Commissioners as part of the whole of government response to the report; if so (a) when; and (b) can any written advice which was received be provided; if not, why not.

(5) Is the $63 million assistance package over 4 years entirely `new' money or does the funding include monies already committed by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Commission or other Government departments in the last Budget.

(6) Were any discussions or advice sought from the Government's Chief General Counsel, Mr Henry Burmester, following his advice to a Senate Estimates Committee in May 1997 that there was no legal impediment such as possible compensation claims, to the Government, providing a carefully worded apology to indigenous people; if so, when was that advice sought and received; if not, why not.
(7) Given Mr Burmester's advice, can you explain why the Government is adamant no apology can be given.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The inter-departmental committee met on 22 July 1997. Committee members then met on either a bilateral or trilateral basis on a number of occasions thereafter.

(2) Prime Minister and Cabinet (Chair); Attorney-General's; Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Communications and the Arts; Health and Family Services; Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Finance; and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).
(3) Yes.

(4) (a) Yes. The matter was raised at a number of ATSIC Board meetings when I was present. In addition, there has been correspondence between the Chairman of ATSIC and myself, and a number of discussions between ATSIC officials and Board members.
(4) (b) No. The correspondence referred to above concerns matters considered by Cabinet.

(5) Of the $63 million allocated $54 million is entirely new money. The remaining $9 million represents additional spending in the area of language and cultural centres and was allocated from ATSIC's discretionary budget.

(6) No. The issue of an apology was not under consideration. The Prime Minister had previously stated the government's position on a formal national apology in response to a question without notice from the Hon Kim Beazley MP, Leader of the Opposition, on 2 June 1997.

(7) An apology could imply that present generations are in some way responsible and accountable for the actions of earlier generations, actions that were sanctioned by the laws of the time, and that were believed to be in the best interests of the children concerned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 6 January 1998:

question.para: With reference to the report The sterilisation of girls and young women in Australia—A legal, medical and social context commissioned by the Federal Disability Discrimination Commissioner and published in December 1997 which indicates that the principles laid down by the High Court were not being complied with and sterilisations are being carried out unlawfully in Australia:

(1) Will an investigation be undertaken to determine the number and type of sterilisations performed on girls and young women with intellectual and physical disability without prior approval by a court or tribunal.
(2) Will steps be taken to prosecute medical practitioners who have performed non-therapeutic sterilisation without court or tribunal approval.

(3) Is the Government prepared to introduce legislative reform to clarify the law in relation to therapeutic and non-therapeutic sterilisations and in relation to what constitutes the `best interests' of the child.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department's analysis of Medicare data since 1992 indicates that only about 200 procedures which would result in sterilisation have been performed on young women and girls aged less than 20, as opposed to the 1,045 claimed in the Report. This total includes procedures legitimately performed for the treatment of a disease or condition, with sterilisation as an unfortunate consequence. It is not possible to ascertain from Medicare data whether these patients have an intellectual or physical disability. The Department has requested a meeting with the Commission and the report researchers to discuss the matter.

(2) While this is largely a matter for the States and Territories, the Commonwealth would of course take steps to investigate any claim that a sterilisation procedure had been conducted in breach of Commonwealth law.

(3) The law in relation to the authorisation of sterilisation procedures for minors is, as stated by the High Court of Australia in Re Marion (1992) 175 CLR 218, that authorisation must be sought from a court or tribunal in order to conduct any such procedure.

In November 1994, against the background of the High Court's decision in Re Marion, the Family Law Council provided a report to the then Attorney-General on `Sterilisation and other Medical Procedures on Children'. That report was considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (`SCAG') in February 1995. At that meeting, a number of State and Territory Ministers expressed some concerns about the centralised procedure for regulating sterilisation proposed in the report The Commonwealth was requested to prepare an issues paper for further consideration by SCAG. The report and the Commonwealth issues paper were subsequently considered by SCAG in March 1996, at which time the States and Territories were asked to indicate their views in writing on the proposals in each.

As a number of States and Territories have not yet responded to this request, it would be premature for the Commonwealth Government to propose a federal legislative response to the sterilisation issue.

In relation to the payment of Medicare benefits for any procedure, it is the Government's aim to ensure that the Medicare Benefits Schedule reflects and encourages appropriate medical practice. The Department is examining whether any changes are needed to the Medicare benefit arrangements to better support the principles laid down by the High Court and is planning to meet with the Report's researchers and the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 6 January 1998:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 650 (Senate Hansard, 22 September 1997, p.6691) in relation to funding provided for research into the so-called `Spalding' approach to literacy at the Tangara School for Girls, Cherrybrook, New South Wales:

(1) With the project due to have been completed at the end of October 1997 and the final report provided by 30 November 1997, was the report completed and the research outcomes published; if so, can a copy of both documents be provided.
(2) Has the final payment been made.
(3) Is it proposed to fund further trials of the `Spalding' approach, if so, can details be provided.
(4) Will the report be reviewed by any other academic education body such as the Australian Council for Education Research.
(5) What, if any, further action is to be taken in relation to the trial.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

answer.para: (1) The final report has been completed and has been provided to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. A copy of the report will be forwarded to Senator Allison after it has been considered by the Government.
(2) The final payment has been made.
(3) No proposal to fund further trials of the Spalding approach is currently being considered.
(4) There are no plans for the report to be reviewed by academic education bodies.
(5) Any further action concerning the trial will be considered in the context of consideration of the final report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 13 January 1998:

question.para: With reference to the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled The Parliamentary Contributory Scheme and the Judges' Pension Scheme:
(1) What action is the Government proposing to take in relation to the report and are there any deadlines for action.
(2) Will the Remuneration Tribunal be made responsible for revising the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme or will this be the responsibility of the Government.
(3) Is it proposed to reform the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme prior to the next federal election.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government will be giving further consideration to the findings of the Committee on parliamentary superannuation. Changes to the method of setting parliamentarians' remuneration are contemplated by the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997, namely setting parliamentarians' remuneration by reference to classifications set by the Remuneration Tribunal rather than by direct linkage to public service SES salaries as at present.

The Government has decided to defer further consideration of the Committee's recommendations on parliamentary superannuation until the new method of setting parliamentarians' remuneration is finalised.

In relation to the judges' pension scheme, the Government agrees that the scheme should be retained. The Government is consulting with the federal judiciary before finalising its view on the proposed modifications to the scheme.

(2) Once the new method of determining parliamentarians' remuneration is resolved, the Government will give further consideration to the arrangements for any further review of parliamentary superannuation.
(3) As indicated in my answer to Question 1, the timing of any consideration of this matter will be dependent on finalisation of the new method of setting parliamentarians' remuneration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 January 1998:

question.para: (1) For the most recent 12 months for which figures are available, how many people had their payments increased as a result of review activity.
(2) What was the average of the increase.
(3) What was the breakdown by payment type of the number of customers and the average increase.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) For the 12 month period from 1/10/96 to 30/9/97 there were 63,639 payment increases as a result of review activity.
(2) The average increase was $24.63 per fortnight.
(3) The breakdown by payment type and average increase follows:
(1) Age Pension, Wife Pension.
(2) Disability Support Pension, Wife Pension, Carer Pension, Child Disability Allowance.
(3) Newstart Allowance, Partner Allowance, Mature Age Allowance, Youth Training Allowance
(4) Family Payment, Family Tax Payment.
(5) Special Benefit, Widows Allowance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 22 January 1998:

question.para: With reference to a statement made during a Senate committee hearing into the telecommunication bills that the department is relegating some standard-setting procedures to the Spectrum Management Agency:
(1) What status will any such agency have.
(2) What aspects of telecommunications technology will it cover.
(3) Will the new body be replacing the current committee TE7 of Standards Australia in setting Australian exposure standards for radiofrequency and microwave radiation.
(4) Who will the agency be representing.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: In 1996 the Government amended the Radiocommunications Act 1992 to give the then Spectrum Management Agency, a health and safety function to protect the health and safety of persons who operate, work on, or use radiocommunications transmitters or receivers or are reasonably likely to be affected by their operation. The functions of the SMA were assumed by the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) from 1 July 1997.

Under section 162 of the Radiocommunications Act, the ACA can make standards for the performance of specified devices; or the maximum permitted level of radio emissions from devices within specified parts of the spectrum.

In October 1997, the ACA released for public comment a discussion paper "Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Energy: Proposal for Mandatory Human Exposure Standards and Compliance Framework" in which the ACA is proposing to mandate the Australian Standard AS2772.1. AS2772.1 is expected to be amended in 1998, but changes to the public exposure limits applicable in the VHF, UHF and microwave bands are not anticipated.

The ACA's proposal may affect the operation of a wide range of radiocommunications and telecommunications devices and services. Compliance through licensing arrangements will be required of operators and users of all transmitters presently licensed under the Radiocommunications Act including broadcasting transmitters, both commercial and public. Manufacturers and importers of devices fitted, or intended to be fitted, with an integral antenna and intended to be used in close proximity to the body will also need to comply with the standard, through labelling requirements.
The ACA anticipates that the proposal will be implemented this year.

The Australian Standard AS2772.1 was developed by the TE7 Committee of Standards Australia, an independent, non-Government organisation. Standards Australia Committee membership is made up of people who are appropriately qualified in matters addressed by the standard. The standard, as with all Australian standards, is constantly reviewed to ensure that it reflects the most up-to-date scientific knowledge. All Australian Standards are subject to a formal public comment process prior to introduction. The Government does not intervene in the standards making process, as it is considered this process should remain independent of Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 22 January 1998:

question.para: With reference to the review into disability advocacy programs which is currently being conducted by the Office of Disability:
(1) What credentials, in terms of knowledge of and experience in disability advocacy, do the current members of the Advocacy Review Steering Committee have.
(2) Will the review take all the previous major reports on advocacy in Australia into account.
(3) During the course of the review will there be consultations with a wide range of advocacy groups as well as people with disabilities.
(4) Will the achievements of disability advocacy groups be built on according to the needs of people with disabilities.
(5) If a community services agenda exists can it be made public.

(6) Will the advocacy program review: (a) set out the reasons for the review; (b) take the historical and contemporary needs people with disabilities have for advocacy services into account; (c) be undertaken in the context of Australia's human rights obligations; and (d) clarify what does and does not constitute `advocacy'.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The current members of the Steering Committee for the Review have a high level of knowledge and experience in the administration and management of Commonwealth programs. One member of the Steering Committee has particularly extensive experience in disability advocacy. In addition, the Steering Committee has received advice from a Reference Group comprising people with direct personal experience of disability advocacy.
(2) Major reports on disability advocacy have been considered during the Review.
(3) The Review has involved extensive consultation with people with disabilities, parents, carers, advocacy users and providers, and disability service providers across Australia.
(4) The experiences and views of a wide range of disability advocacy groups have been considered as part of the Review.

(5) There is no single document known as the Government's community services agenda. The Review has been informed by documents in the public domain, such as the 1996 Coalition Election Health Policy: A Healthy Future.
(6) (a) The stated purpose of the Review is to ensure that Commonwealth resources committed to disability advocacy are targeted in the most effective manner.
(b) Yes.
(c) Relevant human rights obligations are being taken into consideration in the broad context of the Review.
(d) The terms of reference for the Review do not specifically require clarification of what constitutes `advocacy'.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 2 February 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the process by which community-based child care centres may claim child care assistance payments.

(2) How many child care centres in Tasmania are currently in the position of owing or being owed, money to, or by the Commonwealth because the estimate of utilisation numbers provided has been inaccurate.
(3) How do new centres estimate their initial entitlement to child care assistance payments.

(4) How many new centres in Tasmania have been in the position of incorrectly estimating their initial entitlements to childcare assistance because of either overestimating or underestimating utilisation numbers.
(5) What procedures are in place for repayment of over-claimed child care assistance to the Commonwealth.
(6) What procedures are in place for supplementing underpayments of child care assistance to centres.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Childcare Assistance is paid to all eligible child care centres on a three monthly advance/acquit system. Payments are provided to the centres at the beginning of each month. The total payment for each quarter is based on utilisation for the quarter before last.

Centres reduce the fees paid by clients according to the clients' entitlement. At the end of the quarter a claim for Childcare Assistance for the total of this fee reduction is sent by the service to the Department of Health and Family Services and this claim is reconciled against the advance.

(2) The Department of Health and Family Services currently funds approximately 170 child care centres. All centres in Tasmania are likely to be owed or owing an amount to the Commonwealth as their utilisation varies constantly. However, the amounts outstanding or owed are minor in the majority of cases. The amounts outstanding or owed are resolved in the following quarter's payments.
(3) An estimate of the initial advance required is calculated by the Department using the following formula:

Number of approved places multiplied by; Number of hours the service is open multiplied by; Rebatable fee multiplied by; Number of weeks the centre is expected to be open in the period multiplied by; 50% (to reflect utilisation) multiplied by; 50% (to reflect average family entitlement).

Centres are asked to monitor their expenditure on Childcare Assistance closely and contact the Department if the expenditure is significantly less or more than the advance so that an appropriate adjustment can be made.

(4) The total number is not known. Only 4 new centres were opened during 1997. Of these, two underestimated their utilisation marginally and the amount outstanding was paid once the claim was received and processed after the end of the quarter. One centre did not seek an advance for Childcare Assistance and the total amount claimed was paid once the claim was received and processed. The remaining centre was overpaid because it did not reach the estimated utilisation as quickly as projected. This was carried forward to be offset against future Childcare Assistance claims.

(5) Where the amount claimed by a centre is less than that advanced the acquittal is recovered against the next quarter's advance. The delegate may approve recovery to be spread over a longer period should a one off recovery adversely affect operations of the centre.

(6) On provision of documentary evidence additional advances can be made to a centre during the course of a period covered by an advance should expenditure exceed the amount advanced. If they do not request an additional advance the acquittal is made with the first payment for the next quarter.
